div.head: TO HER GRACE THE Dutchess OF CLEAVLAND.
div.p:
ALL Authors whatever in their Dedications are Poets; but I am now to Write to a Lady, who stands as little in need of Flattery, as her Beauty of Art; otherwise, I shou'd prove as ill a Poet to her in my Dedication, as to my Reader in my Play: I can do your Grace no Honour, nor make you more admirers then you have already; yet I can do my self the honour to let the world know, I am the greatest you have; you will pardon me, Madam, for you know, 'tis very hard for a new Author, and Poet too, to govern his Ambition; for Poets, let them pass in the world never so much, for modest, honest men, but begin praise to others, which concludes in themselves; and are like Rooks, who lend people money, but to win it back again, and so leave them in debt to 'em for nothing; they offer Laurel and Incense to their Hero's, but wear it themselves, and perfume themselves. This is true, Madam, upon the honest word of an Author,
who never yet writ Dedication; yet though I cannot lye like them, I am as vain as they, and cannot but publickly give your Grace my humble acknowledgments for the favours I have receiv'd from you: This, I say, is the Poets Gratitude, which in plain English, is only Pride and Ambition; and that the world might know your Grace did me the honour to see my Play twice together; yet perhaps my Enviers of your Favour will suggest 'twas in Lent, and therefore for your Mortification; then, as a jealous Author, I am concern'd not to have your Graces Favours lessen'd, or rather, my reputation; and to let them know, you were pleas'd, after that, to command a Copy from me of this Play; the way without Beauty and Wit, to win a poor Poets heart. 'Tis a sign your Grace understands nothing better, then obliging all the world, after the best and most proper manner; But, Madam, to be obliging to that excess as you are, (pardon me, if I tell you, out of my extream concern, and service for your Grace) is a dangerous quality, and may be very incommode to you; for Civility makes Poets as troublesom, as Charity makes Beggers; and your Grace will be hereafter as much pester'd with such scurvy Offerings as this, Poems, Panegyricks, and the like, as you are now with Petitions: And, Madam, take it from me, no man with Papers in's hand, is more dreadful then a Poet, no, not a Lawyer with his Declarations; Your Grace sure did not well consider what you did, in sending for my Play; you little thought I wou'd have had the confidence to send you a Dedication too: But, Madam, you find I am as unreasonable, and have as little conscience, as if I had driven the Poetick trade
longer then I have, and ne're consider you had enough of the Play; but (having suffer'd now so severely) I beseech your Grace, have a care for the future, take my Counsel, and be (if you can possible) as proud, and ill-natur'd, as other people of Quality, since your quiet is so much concern'd, and since you have more reason then any to value your self; for you have that perfection of Beauty (without thinking it so) which others of your Sex, but think they have; that Generosity in your Actions, which others of your quality, have only in their Promises; that Spirit, Wit, and Judgment, and all other qualifications, which fit Hero's to command, and wou'd make any but your Grace proud. I begin now elevated by my Subject, to write with the Emotion and Fury of a Poet; yet the integrity of an Historian; and I cou'd never be weary, nay, sure this were my only way, to make my Readers never weary too, though they were a more impatient Generation of people then they are. In Fine, speaking thus of your Grace, I shou'd please all the world but you; therefore I must once observe, and obey you▪ against my will, and say no more, then that I am,

closer.signed:
Your Grace's Most obliged, and most humble Servant,
WILLIAM WYCHERLEY
.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: CVstom, which bids the Thief from Cart Harangue,
All those that come to make, and see him hang,
Wills the damn'd Poet (though he knows he's gone)
To greet you, e're his Execution.
Not having fear of Critick 'fore his eyes,
But still rejecting, wholsome, good advice;
He e'en is come to suffer here to day,
For counterfeiting (as you judge) a Play,
Which is against dread Phoebus highest treason,
Damn'd damning Judges, therefore you have reason;
You he do's mean, who for the self same fault,
That damning Priviledge of yours have bought;
So the huge Bankers when they needs must fail,
Send the small Brothers of their trade to Goal;
Whilst they by breaking Gentlemen, are made,
Then more then any scorn, poor men o'th trade;
You hardn'd Renegado Poets, who
Treat Riming Brother, worse then Turk wou'd do;
But vent your Heathenish rage, hang, draw, and quarter,
His Muse will dye to day a fleering Martyr;
Since for ball'd Jest, dull Libel, or Lampoon,
There are who suffer persecution,
With the undaunted briskness of Buffon,
And strict Professors live of Raillery,
Defying Porters Lodge, or Pillory:
For those who yet write on our Poets fate,
Shou'd as Co-sufferers commiserate;
But he in vain their pity now wou'd crave,
Who for themselves (alas) no pity have,
And their own gasping credit will not save;
And those, much less, our Criminal wou'd spare,
Who ne'r in Rhyme transgress, (if such there are)
Well then, who nothing hopes, needs nothing fear;
And he, before your cruel Votes shall do it,
By his despair, declares himself no Poet.

div.head: Love in a Wood, OR, St James's Park.
SCENE. I. Gripes House in the Evening.
div.stage:
Enter My Lady
Flippant, Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: NOT a Husband to be had for mony.

Come, come, I might have been a better House-Wife for my self (as the World goes now,) if I had dealt for an Heir with his Guardian, Uncle, or Mother-in-Law; and you are no better than a Chouse, a Cheat.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I a Cheat Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I am out of my Mony, and my Patience too.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Do not run out of your patience whatever you do,
'Tis a necessary virtue for a Widow without
A Joynture in truly.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.l: Vile Woman, though my Fortune be something
Wasted, my Person's in good repair;
If I had not depended on you, I had had a Husband
Before this time; when I gave you the last five pound,
Did not you promise I should be Marryed by Christmass.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: And had kept my promise if you had Cooperated.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.l: Cooperated, what should I have done?
Tis well known no Woman breathing could use more
Industry to get her a Husband than I have;
Has not my Husbands Scutcheon walk'd as much ground
As the Citizens Signs since the Fire,
That no quarter of the Town might be ignorant
Of the Widow Flippant,

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: 'Tis well known Madam indeed.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Have I not own'd my self (against my Stomach) the relict of a Citizen to credit my Fortune?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: 'Tis confest Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Have I not constantly kept Covent-Garden-Church, St. Martins, the Play-Houses,
Hide-Park, Mulbery-Garden
, and all other the publick Marts where Widows and Mayds are expos'd?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Far be it from me to think you have an Aversion to a Husband;
But why Madam have you refus'd so many good Offers?

sp.speaker: Flip·
sp.p: Good Offers Mrs. Joyner, I'll be sworn I never had an Offer since my late Husbands; if I had had an Offer Mrs. Joyner; there's the thing Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Then your frequent, and publick detestation of Marriage, is thought real;
And if you have had no Offer, there's the thing Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.l: I cannot deny, but I always rail against Marriage
Which is the Widows way to it certainly.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: 'Tis the desperate way, of the desperate Widows, in truly.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Wou'd you have us as tractable as the Wenches that eat Oatmeal; and fool'd like them too.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: If no body were wiser then I, I should think, since the Widow wants the natural alurement which the Virgin has, you ought to give men all other incouragements in truly.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Therefore on the contrary, because the Widows Fortune (whether suppos'd, or real) is her chiefest Bait, the more chary she seems of it, and the more she withdraws it, the more eagerly the busie gaping frye will bite: with us Widows Husbands are got like Bishopricks, by saying no; and I tell you, a young Heir is as shie of a Widow, as of a Rook, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: I can alledge nothing against your practice,
But your ill success; and indeed you must use

Another Method with Sir
Simon Addleplot
.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Will he be at your House at the hour?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: He'll be there by ten, 'tis now nine,
I warrant you he will not fail.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.l: I'll warrant you then I will not fail,
For 'tis more then time I were sped

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Mr. Dapperwit has not been too busie with you, I hope your experience has taught you to prevent a mischance.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: No, no, my mischance (as you call it) is greater then that; I have but three Months to reckon, e're I lye down with my Port and Equipage; and must be delivered a Woman, a Foot-man, and a Coach-man. For my Coach must down, unless I can get Sir Simon to draw with me.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: He will payr with you exactly if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Ah Mrs. Joyner, nothing grieves me like putting down my Coach; for the fine Cloathes, the fine Lodgings; let 'em go; for a Lodging is as unnecessary a thing to a Widow that has a Coach, as a Hat to a Man that has a good Peruque, for as you see about Town she is most properly at home in her Coach, she eats, and drinks, and sleeps in her Coach; and for her Visits she receives them in the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Joyn,
sp.l: Ay, ay, let the Men keep Lodgings
(As you say Madam) if they will.

div.stage:
Gripe
and Sir
Simon Addleplot
following him as his Man in the Habit of a Clarke at one door, and Mrs.
Martha
at the other
.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Do you think if things had been with me as they have been, I would ever have hous'd with this counter fashion Brother of mine, (who hates a Vest as much as a Surplice) to have my Patches assaulted every day; at Dinner my Freedom sensured, and my Visitants shut out of Doors; poor Mr. Dapperwit cannot be admitted.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: He knows him too well to keep his Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: He is a censorious ridged Fop, and knows nothing.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
So, so—
Behind.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
He is hear.
Aside.

To my Lady
Flip.
Nay with your pardon Madam, I must contradict you there. He is a prying Common-Wealths-man, an implacable Majestrate, a sturdy pillar of his cause, and—

But oh me is your Worship so near then? if I had
To Gripe.
Thought you had heard me—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Why, why Mrs. Joyner,
I have said as much of my self e're now,
And without vanity I profess.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: I know your Virtue is proof against Vain-glory;
But the truth to your face, looks like flattery in your Worships servant.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: No, no, say what you will of me in that kind,
Far be it from me to suspect you of flattery.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: In truly your Worship knows your self,
And knows me, for I am none of those—

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.l:
Now they are in—
Aside.
Mrs. Joyner I'll go before to your House,

You'll be sure to come after me.
Exit Flippant.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Immediately; but as I was saying,
I am none of those—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No Mrs. Joyner, you cannot sew Pillows,
Under Folks elbows; you cannot hold a Candle to the Divel; you cannot tickle a Trout to take him, you—

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Lord how well you do know me indeed;
And you shall see I know your Worship as well,
You cannot backslide from your Principles;
You cannot be terrify'd by the laws;
Nor brib'd to Alegiance by Office or Preferment;
You—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my praise must not interrupt yours.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: With your Worships pardon, (In truly) I must on.

sp.speaker: Gripe,
sp.p: I am full of your praise, and it will run over.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Nay sweet Sir, you are—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Nay sweet Mrs. Joyner, you are—

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Nay good your Worship, you are
Stops her mouth with his Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I say you are—

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I must not be rude with your Worship.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: You are a Nursing mother to the Saints;
Through you they gather together;
Through you they fructify and encrease; and through you
The Child cries from out of the Hand-Basket.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Through you Virgins are marryed or provided
For as well; through you the Reprobates Wife
Is made a Saint; and through you the Widow is not
Disconsolate, nor misses her Husband.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Through you—

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Indeed you will put me to the blush

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Blushes are badges of Imperfection,
Saints have no shame: You are the flowr of Matrons Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You are the Pink of curtious Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Gripe,
sp.p: You are the Muffler of Secresy

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You are the Head-band of Justice.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Thank you sweet Mrs. Joyner, do you think
So indeed? you are—
You are the Bonefire of Devotion.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You are the Bellows of Zeal.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You are the Cup-board of Charity.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You are the Fob of Liberality,

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You are the Rivet of sanctify'd Love or Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: You are the Picklock and Dark-Lanthorn of Policy;
And in a word, a Conventicle of Virtues.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Your Servant, your servant sweet Mrs. Joyner,
You have stopt my mouth.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Your Servant, your servant sweet Alderman,
I have nothing to say.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: The half Pullet will be cold Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Mrs. Joyner you shall Sup with me.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Indeed I am engag'd to Supper with some
Of your man's Friends; and I came on purpose.
To get leave for him too.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I cannot deny you any thing; but I have forgot to tell you what a kind of Fellow my Sisters Dapperwit is; before a full Table of the Coffee-house sages he had the impudence to hold an Argument against me in the defence of Vests and Protections; and therefore I forbid him my house; besides when he came, I was forc'd to lock up my Daughter for fear of him, nay, I think the poor Child her self was afraid of him: come hither Child, were you not afraid of Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Martha.
sp.l: Yes indeed, Sir, he is a terrible man.

Yet I durst meet with him in the Piazzo at midnight.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: He shall never come into my doors again.

sp.speaker: Marth.
sp.p: Shall Mr. Dapperwit never come hither again then?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, Child.

sp.speaker: Marth.
sp.p: I am afraid he will.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Marth.
sp.l:
I warrant you then I'le go to him.
Aside.
I am glad of that, for I hate him as much as a Bishop.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Thou art no Child of mine, if thou dost not hate Bishops and Wits: Well, Mrs. Joyner, I'le keep you no longer. Jonas, wait on Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Good night to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: But stay, stay Mrs. Joyner, have you spoken with the Widow Crossbite about her little Daughter, as I desir'd.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I will to morrow early, it shall be the first thing I'le do after my Prayers.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: If Dapperwit should contaminate her; I cannot rest till I have redeem'd her from the Jaws of that Lyon, good night.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Good Gentleman.
Exeunt Gripe and Martha.

div.stage: Manent Sir. Simon Addleplot and Joyner.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Hah, hah, ha, Mrs Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Hah, hah, ha— let us make haste to your House, or I shall burst, faith and troth to see what Fools you and I make of these people.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I will not rob you of any of the credit, I am but a feeble Instrument, you are the Engeneer.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Remember what you say now when things succeed, and do not tell me then, I must thank your wit for all.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: No in truly, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay I'm sure Dapperwit and I have been partners in many an Intrigue, and he uses to serve me so.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: He is an ill man to intrigue with, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I, so are all your Wits; a pox, if a mans understanding be not so publick as theirs, he cannot do a wise action but they go away with the honour of it, if he be of their acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Why do you keep such Acquaintance then?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: There is a Proverb, Mrs. Joyner, You may know him by his Company.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: No, no, to be thought a man of parts, you shou'd always keep Company with a man of less wit then your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: That's the hardest thing in the world for me to do, saith and troth.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: What, to find a man of less wit then your self?
Pardon my Raillery, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, no, I cannot keep Company with a Fool, I wonder how men of parts can do't, there's something in't.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: If you cou'd all your wise actions wou'd be your own, and your money wou'd be your own too.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Nay, faith and troth that's true; for your Wits are plaguely given to borrow; they'l borrow of their Wench, Coach-man, or Link-boy their hire. Mrs.
Joyner, Dapperwit
has that trick with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Why will you keep Company with him then, I say? for to be plain with you, you have followed him so long, that you are thought but his Culley; for every Wit has his Culley, as every Squire his lead Captain.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.l: I his Culley? I his Culley Mrs. Joyner!
Lord that I should be thought a Culley to any Wit breathing.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: Nay do not take it so to heart, for the best Wits
Of the Town, are but Culleys themselves.

sp.speaker: Sir Simon.
sp.p: To whom, to whom, to whom, Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: To Sem'steresses, and Bawds.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.l: To your knowledge, Mrs. Joyner.
There I was with her.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: To Taylors and Vintners, but especially to the French Houses.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: But Dapperwit is a Culley to none of them for he ticks.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I care not; but I wish you were a Culley to none but me, that's all the hurt I wish you,

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Thank you Mrs. Joyner; well I will throw off Dapperwits acquaintance when I am marryed, and will only be a Culley to my Wife, and that's no more then the wisest Husband of 'em all is.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Then you think you shall carry Mrs. Martha?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.l: Your hundred Guineys are
As good as in your Lap.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.l: But I am afraid this double plot of yours
Should fail, you wou'd sooner succeed,
If you only design'd upon Mrs. Martha,
Or only upon my Lady Flippant.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Nay then you are no Woman of Intrigue, faith and troth 'tis good to have two strings to one Bow; if Mrs. Martha be coy; I tell the Widow I put on my disguise for her; But if Mrs. Martha be kind to Jonas, Sir
Simon Addleplot
will be false to the Widow, which is no more then Widows are us'd to, for a promise to a Widow is as seldome kept as a Vow made at Sea, as Dapperwit says.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I am afraid they shou'd discover you

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You have nothing to fear, you have your twenty Guineys in your pocket for helping me into my Service, and if I get into Mrs. Martha's quarters you have a hundred more, if into the Widdows fifty, happy goe luckey, will her Ladiship be at your house at the hour.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Then you shall see when I am Sir
Simon Addleplot
and my self, I'll look like my self, now I am Jonas I look like an Ass; you never thought Sir
Simon Addleplot
cou'd have look'd so like an Ass by his ingenuity.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay do not flatter faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Come let us goe 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I will carry the Widdow to the French house.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: If she will goe.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: If she will go; why, did you ever know a Widow refuse a treat? no more then a Lawyer a Fee faith and troth; yet I know too.

l.hi: No treat, sweet words, good meen, but sly Intrigue
That must at length, the jilting Widow fegue.

House, a Table, Wine, and Candles.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Ranger, let's have no drinking to night.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Ranger, let's have no Dapperwit to night.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Vincent.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A pox, I hate his impertinent Chat more then he does the honest Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: But why shou'd you force Wine upon us? we are not all of your gusto.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But why shou'd you force your chaw'd jests, your damn'd ends of your mouldy Lampoones, and last years Sonnets upon us, we are not all of your gusto?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: The Wine makes me sick, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Thy Rhymes make me spew.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
At Reparty already, come Vincent, I know you would
Gives him the Glass.
rather have him pledge you here Dapperwit; but why are you so eager to have him drink always.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Because he is so eager to talk always, and there is no other way to silence him.

sp.speaker: Wait.
sp.p: Here is a Gentleman desires to speak with Mr. Vincent.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I come.
Exit Vin.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: He may drink because he is obliged to the Bottle, for all the wit and courage he has, 'tis not free and natural like yours.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: He has more courage then wit, but wants neither.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: As a Pump gone dry, if you powr no Water down you will get none out, so—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay I bar similes too, to night.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Why is not the thought new, don't you apprehend it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Well, well, will you comply with his sottishness too, and hate brisk things in complaisance to the ignorant dull age? I believe shortly 'twill be as hard to find a patient friend to communicate ones wit to, as a faithful friend to communicate ones secret to. Wit has a few true Judges as painting I see.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: All people pretend to be judges of both.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: I they pretend— but set you aside,
And two more.—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But why has Vincent neither courage nor wit.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
He has no courage because he beat his Wench for giving me
les douces yeux once
; and no wit because he does not comprehend my thoughts; and he is a Son of a Whore for his ignorance; I take ignorance worse from any man then the Lye, because it is as much as to say I am no Wit..
Vincent Returns.
You need not take any notice, though, to him of what I say.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ranger there is a Woman below, in a Coach wou'd speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
With me.
Exit Ran.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: This Ranger, Mr. Vincent, is as false to his Friend as his Wench.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: You have no reason to say so,
But because he is absent.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: 'Tis disobliging to tell a Man of his faults to his face, if he had but your grave parts, and manly wit, I shou'd adore him; but a pox he is a meer Buffon, a Jack-pudding let me perish.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You are an ungrateful fellow, I have heard him maintain you had wit, which was more then ere you cou'd do for your self; I thought you had own'd him your Maecenas.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: A pox he cannot but esteem me, 'tis for his honour; but I cannot but be just for all that, without favour or affection, yet I confess I love him so well, that I wish he had but the hundredth part of your courage.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: He has had the courage to save you from many a beating to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Dap,
sp.p: Come, come, I wish the man well, and next to you, better then any man, and I am sorry to say it, he has not a courage to snuff a Candle with his fingers; when he is drunk indeed, he dares get a Clap, or so— and swear at a Constable.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Detracting Fop, when did you see him desert his Friend.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
You have a rough kind of Raillery Mr. Vincent, but since you will have it, (though I love the man heartily, I say) he deserted me once in breaking of Windows, for fear of the Constable,
Ranger Returns.
but you need not take notice to him, of what I tell you; I hate to put a man to the blush.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I have had just now a visit from my Mistress, who is as jealous of me, as a Wife of her Husband when she lies in; My Cosin Lydia, you have heard me speak of her.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But she is more troublesom then a Wife that lies in, because she follows you to your haunts; why do you allow her that priviledge before her time?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Faith, I may allow her any priviledge and be to hard for her yet; how do you think I have cheated her to night? Women are poor credulous Creatures, easily deceived.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: We are poor credulous Creatures, when we think 'em so.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Intending a Ramble to St. James's Park to night, upon some probable hopes of some fresh Game I have in chase, I appointed her to stay at home, with a promise to come to her within this hour, that she might not foil the scent and prevent my sport.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: She'll be even with you when you are married I warrant you: in the mean time here's her health Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Now had he rather be at the window writing her Anagram in the Glass with his Diamond, or biting his nails in the corner, for a fine thought, to come and divert us with at the Table.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: No a pox I have no wit to night, I am as barren and hide-bound as one of your damn'd scribling Poets, who are sotts in company for all their wit, as a Miser poor for all his mony; how do you like the thought.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Drink, drink.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Well I can drink this, because I shall be repreiv'd presently.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Who will be so civil to us.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Sir
Simon Addleplot
, I have bespoke him a Supper here, for he treats to night a new rich Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: That Spark who has his fruitless designs upon the bed-ridden rich Widow, down to the sucking Heiresses in her pissing cloute; He was once the sport, but now the publick grievance of all the fortunes in Town; for he watches them like a younger Brother that is afraid to be mump'd of his snip, and they cannot steal a Marriage, nor stay their stomachs, but he must know it.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: He has now pitch'd his Nets for Gripe's Daughter the rich Scrivener, and serves him as a Clerk to get admission to her, which the watchful Fop her Father, denies to all others.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I thought you had been nibling at her once, under pretence of love to her Aunt.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I confess I have the same design yet, and Addleplot is but my Agent whilst he thinks me his; he brings me Letters constantly from her, and carries mine back.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Still betraying your best friends.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I cannot in honour but betray him (let me perish,) the poor young Wench is taken with my person, and wou'd scratch through fowr walls to come to me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign she is kept up close indeed.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Betray him, I'll not be a Traytor to Love for any man.

div.stage:
Sir Simon Addleplot
to them with the Waitor
.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Know 'em, you are a sawcy Jack-straw to question me, (faith and troth) I know every body, and every body knows me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Sir Simon, Sir Simon, Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And you are a welcom man to every body.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim,
sp.p: Now son of a Whore, do I know the Gentlemen? a dog, he wou'd have had a shilling of me before he wou'd let me come to you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: The Rogue has been bred at Court sure;
Get you out Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He has been bred at a French house, where they are more unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Here's to you Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I cannot drink, for I have a Mistress within, though I wou'd not have the people of the house to know it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You need not be asham'd of your Mistresses, for they are commonly rich.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: And because she is rich, I wou'd conceal her, for I never had a rich Mistress yet, but one or other got her from me presently faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But this is an ill place to conceal a Mistress in, every Waiter is an Intelligencer to your Rivals.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I have ' trick for that, I let no Waiters come into the Room, I'll lay the Cloth my self rather.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But who is your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Your Servant,— your Servant,— Mr. Ranger.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Come will you pledge me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, I'll spare your Wine, if you will spare me Dapperwits company, I came for that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You do us a double favour, to take him and leave the Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Come, come Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Do not go unless he will suffer us to see his Mistress too.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Come, come man.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Would you have me so incivil as to leave my company; they'll take it ill?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I cannot find her talk without thee; pray Gentlemen perswade Mr. Dapperwit to go with me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: We will not hinder him of better company.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Yours is too good to be left rudely.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen I wou'd desire your company too, if you knew the Lady.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: They know her as well as I, you say I know her not.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
You are not every body.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Perhaps we do know the Lady Sir Simon.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You do not, you do not, none of you ever saw her in your lives; but if you cou'd be secret, and civil.—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: We have drunk yet but our Bottles a peice.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: But will you be civil Mr. Vincent?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: He dares not look a Woman in the face under three Bottles.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Come along then, but can you be civil Gentlemen? will you be civil Gentlemen? pray be civil if you can, and you shall see her.
Exit Sir
Sim.

div.stage:
Returns with my Lady
Flippant
and Mrs.
Joyner

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
How has he got his Jilt here?
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
The widow Flippant!—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Is this the Woman we never saw.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Does he bring us into company, and Dapperwit one? though I had marryed the Fool, I thought to have reserv'd the Wit as well as other Ladies.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, look as long as you will Madam, you will find them civil Gentlemen and good Company.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I am not in doubt of their civility but yours,

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
You'll never leave snubbing your Servants, did you not promise to use him kindly.
Behind.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
'Tis true.
Aside.
We wanted no good company, Sir Simon, as long as we had yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: But they wanted good company, therefore I forc'd them to accept of yours.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: They will not think the Company good they were forc'd into certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: A pox I must be using the words in fashion though I never have any luck with 'em, Mrs. Joyner help me off.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I suppose, Madam, he means the Gentlemen wanted not inclination to your company, but confidence to desire so great an honour, therefore he forc'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What makes this Bawd here? sure Mistress you Bawds should be like the small Cards, though at first you make up the Pack, yet when the play begins, you should be put out as useless.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Well, well, jibeing companion, you wou'd have the
Pimps kept in only? you would so?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What they are quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Pimp and Bawd agree now a days like Doctor an Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Try Madam if they are not civil Gentlemen, talk with e'm, while I go lay the cloath no Waiter comes here:

My Mother us'd to tell me, I should avoid all occasions of talking before my Mistress, because silence is a sign of love as well as prudence.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Methinks you look a little yellow on't
Sir Simon
laying the Cloath
.
Mr. Dapperwit; I hope you do not sensure me because you find me passing away a night with this Fool; he is not a man to be jealous of sure.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: You are not a Lady to be jealous of sure.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: No certainly, but why doe you look as if you were jealous then.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: If I had met you in Wheatstones-Park with a drunken Foot-Soldier, I should not have been jealous of you.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Fye, fye, now you are jealous certainly, for people always when they grow jealous, grow rude; but I can pardon it since it proceeds from love certainly.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
I am out of all hopes to be rid of this eternal old acquaintance, when I jear her, she thinks her self prais'd, now I call her Whore in plain english, she thinks I am jealous
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Dapperwit be not so sensorious, I speak for your sake, not my own, for jealousie is a great torment, but my honor cannot suffer certainly.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: No certainly, but the greatest torment I have is your Love.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Alas sweet Mr. Dapperwit, indeed Love is a torment, but 'tis a sweet torment; but Jealousie is a bitter torment; I do not go about to cure you of the torment of my love.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign so.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Come, come, look up man, is that a Rival to contest with you?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
I will contest with no Rival, not with my old Rival your Coach-man, but they have heartily my resignation, and to do you a favour, but my self a greater, I will help tye the knot
you are fumbling for now, betwixt your Culley here, and you.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Go, go, I take that kind of jealousie worst of all, to suspect I would be debauch'd to beastly Matrimony; but who are those Gentlemen pray?— are they men of Fortunes Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Do you believe so indeed; Gentlemen.—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: If the civility we owe to Ladies, had not controul'd our envy to Mr. Dapperwit, we had interrupted e're this your private conversation.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Your interruption, Sir, had been most civil, and obliging, for our discourse was of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: That is a subject Madam, as grateful as common.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: O fye, fye, are you of that opinion too? I cannot suffer any to talk of it in my company.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Are you married then Madam?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: No certainly.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I am sure so much Beauty cannot despair of it.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Dispair of it—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Only those that are married, or cannot be married, hate to hear of marriage.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Yet you must know, Sir, my aversion to marriage is such, that you nor no man breathing, shall ever perswade me to it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Curs'd be the man shou'd do so rude a thing as to perswade you to any thing against your inclination; I wou'd not do it for the World, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Come, come, though you seem to be a civil Gentleman, I think you no better then your Neighbours; I do not know a man of you all, that will not thrust a Woman up into a corner, and then talk an hour to her impertinently of marriage.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You wou'd find me another man in a corner, I assure you, Madam, for you shou'd not have a word of marriage from me, whatsoever you might find in my actions of it; I hate talking as much as you.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I hate it extreamly.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I am your man then, Madam, for I sind just the same fault with your Sex as you do with ours; I ne're cou'd have to do with a Woman in my life, but still she wou'd be impertinently talking of marriage to me.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Observe that, Mrs. Joyner.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Ranger let's go, I had rather drink with Mr. Vincent, then stay here with you; besides 'tis Park-time.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I come.
To Dap.
Since you are a Lady that hate marriage, I'll do you the service to withdraw the company, for those that hate marriage, hate loss of time.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Will you go then, Sir, but before you go, Sir, pray tell me is your aversion to marriage real?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: As real as yours.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
If it were no more real then mine.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
But do you hate marriage certainly?
Plucks him back.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Come, I canot believe it, you dissemble it, only because I pretend it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Do you but pretend it then, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
I shall discover my self—
Aside.

I mean, because I hold against it, you do the same in complaisance; for I have heard say, cunning men think to bring the coy and untractable women to tameness, as they do some mad people by humoring their frenzies.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I am none of those cunning men, yet have too much wit to entertain the presumption of designing upon you.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: 'Twere no such presumption neither.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Come away, 's death don't you see your danger?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Those aims are for Sir Simon, good night, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Will you needs go then? the gentlemen are a going, Sir Simon, will you let 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, if you cannot keep 'em, how should I?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Stay, Sir, because you hate marriage, I'll sing you a new Song against it.

lg.l: For either she's false or she's jealous;
Who nothing will ask us, or tell us.
Nor chaffers by way of Indenture,
But takes her kind man at a venture.
Without an Act, Process, or Warning,
You may be divorc'd in the morning.
Their Bratts connot be any other;
Have always a Punk to their Mother.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Though it be the fashion for women of quality to sing any Song whatever, because the words are not distinguish'd; yet I should have blush'd to have done it now, but for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: The Song is edifying, the Voice admirable, and once more, I am your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: What, will you go too, Mr. Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Dapperwit, do not you go too,

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I am engag'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Well, if we cannot have their company, we will not have their Room, ours is a private back Room; they have paid their reckoning, let's go thither again.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: But pray, sweet Mr. Dapperwit, do not go; keep him Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
I cannot keep him.
Exeunt Vin. Ran. Dap.

l.hi: It is impossible; (the World is so,

One cannot keep ones Friend, and Mistress too.
Ex. Omnes.

div.head: SCENE. I. St. James's Park at night.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: HAng me if I am not pleas'd extreamly with this new fashioned catterwouling, this midnight coursing in the Park.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: A man may come after Supper with his three Bottles in his head, reel himself sober, without reproof from his Mother, Aunt, or grave relation.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: May bring his bashful Wench, and not have her put out of countenance by the impudent honest women of the Town.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And a man of wit may have the better of the dumb shew, of well trim'd Vest, or fair Perruque; no man's now is whitest.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And now no woman's modest, or proud, for her blushes are hid, and the rubies on her lips are died, and all sleepy and glimmering eyes have lost their attraction.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And now a man may carry a Bottle under his arm, instead of his Hat, and no observing spruce Fop will miss the Crevat that lies on ones shoulder, or count the pimples on ones face.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And now the brisk reparty ruins the complaisant Cringe, or wise Grimace, something 'twas, we men of virtue always lov'd the night.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: O blessed season.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: For good-Fellows.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: For Lovers.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And for the Muses.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: When I was a Boy I lov'd the night so well, I had a strong vocation to be a Bellman's Apprentice.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And I to attend the Waits of Westminster, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But why do we not do the duty of this and such other places, walk, censure, and speak ill of all we meet?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: 'Tis no fault of mine, let me perrish.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Satyrical gentlemen, this is not your time, you cannot distinguish a Friend from a Fop.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: No matter, no matter, they will deserve amongst 'em the worst we can say.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.p: Who comes here, Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
By the toss of his head, training of his
People walking slowly over the Stage.
feet, and his elbows playing at bo-peep behind his back, it should be my Lord Easy.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And who the woman?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: My Lord, what d'ye call's Daughter
That had a Child by—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Dapperwit, hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: How are you concern'd?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Her Brother's an honest Fellow, and will drink his Glass.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Prithee,
Vincent; Dapperwit
did not hinder drinking to night, though he speak against it; why then shou'd you interrupt his sport? now let him talk of any body.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: So he will, till you cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Why shou'd you in all ocasions thwart him, contemn him, and maliciously look grave at his jests only?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why do's he always rail against my friends then, and my best friend a Beer-glass?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Dapperwit, be your own Advocate, my Game I think is before me there?
Exit Ran.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: This Ranger, I think has all the ill qualities, of all your Town Fops, leaving his company for a spruce Lord, Or a Wench.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay, if you must rail at your own best friends, I may forgive you, railing at mine.

div.stage:
Lydia
and my Lady
Flippant
walking over the Stage

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
False Ranger, shall I find thee here?
Aside.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Those are women, are they not?
To Dap.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
The least, seems to be my Lucy sure.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Faith, I think I dare speak to a woman in the dark, let's try.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: They are persons of quality of my acquaintance; hold.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay, if they are persons of quality of your acquaintance, I may be the bolder with 'em.

div.stage:
The Ladies go off, they follow them
; Lydia and Flippant re-enter.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I come hither to make a discovery to night.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Of my love to you certainly; for no body but you cou'd have debauch'd me to the Park certainly; I wou'd not return another night, if it were to redeem my dear husband from his grave.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I believe you, but to get another Widow.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Another Husband, another Husband, soh!

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: There does not pass a night here, but many a match is made.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: That a woman of honour shou'd have the word match in her mouth: but I hope, Madam, the fellows do not make honourable Love here, do they? I abominate honourable Love, upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
If they should make honourable Love here, I know you would prevent 'em.
Vincent and Dapperwit
Re-enter and walk slowly towards them.
But here come two men will inform you what they do.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Do they come? are they men certainly?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Prepare for an assault, they'l put you to't.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Will they put us to't certainly? I was never put to't yet; if they shou'd put us to't, I shou'd drop down, down certainly.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I believe, truly, you wou'd not have power to run away.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Therefore I will not stay the push they come, they come, oh the fellows come!
Flippant
runs away
, Lydia
follows, and
Vincent, and Dapperwit
after them
.
Flippant
Re-enters at to'ther door alone
.
So I am got off clear, I did not run from the men, but my companion, for all their brags, men have hardly courage to set upon us, when our number is equal; now they shall see I defie 'em,
for we women have always most courage when we are alone; but a Pox— the lazie Rogues come not, or they are Drunk and cannot run: Oh drink, abominable drink instead of inflaming Love, it quenches it, and for one Lover it incourages, it makes a thousand impotent. Curse on all Wine, even Renish-Wine and Sugar—
Enter Addleplot
muffled in a Cloak
.
But Fortune will not see me want, here comes a single Bully, I wish he may stand;
sp.l: For now anights the jostling Nymph is bolder,
Then modern Satyr with his Cloak o're shoulder.
sp.p:
Well met Sir.
She puts on her Mask.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How shall I know that, forsooth, who are you? do you know me?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Who are you? don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Not I faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I am glad on't, for no man e're lik'd a woman the better for having known her before.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I, but then one can't be so free with a new acquaintance, as with an old one; she may deny one the civility.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Not till you ask her.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: But I am afraid to be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir, you cannot dis-oblige us women more, then in distrusting us.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pish, what shou'd one ask for, when you know on's meaning? but shall I deal freely with you?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I love of my life men should deal freely with me; there are so few men will deal freely with one—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Are you not a Fireship? a Punk, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I love Raillery.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Faith and troth I do not railly, I deal freely.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: This is the time and place for freedom, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Are you handsom?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Jone's as good as my Lady in the dark certainly; but men that deal freely, never ask questions certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How then! I thought to deal freely, and put a woman to the question, had been all one.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: But let me tell you, those that deal freely indeed, take a woman by—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What, what, what, what?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: By the hand and lead 'em aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Now I understand you come along then.

div.stage: Enter Torches and Musick at a distance.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
What unmannerly Rascals are those that bring light into the Park? 'twill not be taken well from 'em by the women certainly; still disappointed—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh the Fidles, the Fidles, I sent for them hither to oblige the women, not offend 'em; for I intend to Serenade the whole Park to night; but my Frolick is not without an intrigue, faith and troth; for I know the Fidles will call the whole Herd of vizard Masks together; and then shall I discover if a stray'd Mistress of mine be not amongst 'em, whom I treated to night at the French-house; but as soon as the Jilt had eat up my meat, and drank her two bottles, she run away from me, and left me alone.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
How! is it he! Addleplot, that I cou'd not know him by his faith and troth.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Now I wou'd understand her tricks, because I intend to Marry her, and shou'd be glad to know what I must trust to.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
So thou shalt, but not yet.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Though I can give a great guess already; for if I have any intrigue on sense in me, she is as arrant a Jilt, as ever pull'd pillow from under husbands head (faith and troth) moreover she is bow-legg'd, hopper-hipp'd, and betwixt Pomatum and Spanish Red, has a Complexion like a Holland Cheese, and no more Teeth left, then such as give a Haust-goust to her breath; but she is rich (faith and troth.)

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Oh Rascal! he has heard some body else say all this of me; but I must not discover my self, lest I should be disappointed of my revenge, for I will marry him.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What gone? come then, strike up my lads.

div.stage: Enter Men and Women in Vizards, and Dance.

Addleplot
for the most part standing still in a Cloak and Vizard, but sometimes going about peeping, and examining the Womens cloaths; the Dance ended.

Exeunt Dancers, Torches, Musick, and
Addleplot.

Enter Flippant, Lydia,
after them
Vincent, Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Nay, if you stay any longer, I must leave you again.
To Lydia.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
We have over-taken them at last again,
Flip.
going off
.
these are they, they separate too, and that's but a challenge to us.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Let me perish Ladies—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Nay, good Madam, let's unite, now here's the common enemy upon us.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Dam me Ladies—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Hold, a Pox you are to rough, let me perish Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Not for want of breath, Gentlemen, wee'l stay rather.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: For want of your favour, rather sweet Ladies.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: That's Dapperwit, false villain; but he must not know I am here; if he should, I should lose his thrice agreeable company, and he would run from me, as fast as from the Bayliffs. What you will not talk with 'em I hope?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Yes, but I will.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Then you are a Park-woman certainly, and you will take it kindly if I leave you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
No, you must not leave me.
Apart.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Then you must leave them.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I'le see if they are worse company then you first.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Monstrous impudence, will you not come?
Pulls Lydia.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I never suffer any violence to be us'd to a woman, but what I do my self; she must stay, and you must not go.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Unhand me you rude fellow.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay, now I am sure you will stay and be kind; for coyness in a woman is as little sign of true modesty, as huffing in a man, is of true courage.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Use her gently, and speak soft things to her.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Now do I guess I know my Coxcomb.
Aside.
Sir, I am extremely glad I am fallen into the hands of a Gentleman, that can speak soft things; and this is so fine a night to hear soft things in; moring I shou'd have said.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
It will not be morning, dear Madam, till you pull off your Mask; that I think was brisk—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Indeed, dear Sir, my face would frighten back the Sun.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: With glories, more radient then his own;

I keep up with her I think.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But why wou'd you put me to the trouble of lighting the World, when I thought to have gone to sleep?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: You only can do it, dear Madam, let me perrish.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But why wou'd you (of all men) practice Treason against your friend Phoebus, and depose him for a meer stranger?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
I think he knows me.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But he does not do you justice, I believe, and you are so positively cock-sure of your wit, you wou'd refer to a meer stranger your Plea to the Bay-tree.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
She jears me, let me perish.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Dapperwit, a little of your aid, for my Lady's invincibly dumb.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Wou'd mine had been so too.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I have us'd as many arguments to make her speak, as are requisite to make other women hold their tongues.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Well, I am ready to change sides, yet before I go, Madam; since the Moon consents, now I shou'd see your face, let me desire you to pull off your Mask, which to a handsom Lady is a favour, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I must not be long in debt to you the obligation; pray, let▪ me here you recite some of your verses, which to a Wit, is a favour I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Madam, it belongs to your sex to be oblidg'd first; pull off your Mask, and I'll pull out my paper.

Brisk again of my side.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be in vain, for you wou'd want a Candle now.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
I dare not make use again of the lustre of her
Aside.
face: I'll wait upon you home then, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Faith no, I believe it will not be much to our advantages, to bring my face, or your Poetry to light, for I hope, you have yet a pretty good opinion of my face, and so have I of your wit; but if you are for proving your wit, why do not you write a Play?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Because 'tis now no more reputation to write a Play, then it is honour to be a Knight: your true wit despises the title of Poet, as much as your true gentleman the title of Knight; for as a man may be a Knight and no Gentleman, so a man may be a Poet and no Wit, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how are you dignifi'd or distinguish'd amongst the rates of Wits? and how many rates are there?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: There are as many degrees of Wits, as of Lawyers; as there is first your Sollicitor, then your Aturney, then your Pleading-Counsel, then your Chamber-Counsel, and then your Judge; so there is first your Court-Wit, your Coffee-Wit, your Poll-Wit or Pollitick-Wit, your Chamber-Wit or Scribble-Wit, and last of all, your Judg-Wit or Critick.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But are there as many Wits as Lawyers? Lord, what will become of us? what employment can they have? how are they known?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: First, your Court-Wit is a fashionable, insinuating, flattering, cringing, grimacing, fellow; and has wit enough to sollicit a suit of Love; and if he fail, he has malice enough to ruin the woman with a dull Lampoon, but he rails still at the man that is absent, for you must know, all Wits rail; and his wit properly lies in combing Perruques, matching Ribbonds, and being severe as they call it, upon other peoples cloaths.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now, what is the Coffee-Wit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: He is a lying, censorious, gossiping, quibling wretch, and sets people together by the ears over that sober drink Coffee; he is a Wit, as he is a commentator upon the Gazet, and he rails at the Pyrats of Algiere, the Grand Signior of Constantinople, and the Christian Grand Signior.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What kind of man is your Poll-Wit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: He is a fidgeting, busie, dogmatical, hot-headed Fop, that speaks always in sentences and proverbs, (as others in similitudes) and he rails perpetually against the present government; his Wit lies in projects and monopolies, and penning speeches for young Parliament men.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But what is your Chamber-Wit or Scribble-Wit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
He is a poring, melancholy, modest Sot, asham'd of the world; he searches all the Records of Wit, to compile a breviate
of them for the use of Players, Printers, Book-sellers, and sometimes Cooks, and Tabacca-men; he imploys his railing against the ignorance of the age, and all that have more mony then he.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now your last.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Your Judg-Wit or Critick, is all these together, and yet has the wit to be none of them; he can think, speak, write, as well as all the rest, but scorns (himself a Judg) to be judg'd by posterity; he rails at all the other Classes of Wits, and his wit lies in damming all but himself: he is your true Wit..

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Then, I suspect you are of his Form.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I cannot deny it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Dapperwit, you have been all this time on the wrong side, for you love to talk all, and here's a Lady wou'd not have hindred you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
A pox, I have been talking too long indeed here; for Wit is lost upon a silly weak woman, as well as courage.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I have us'd all common means to move a womans tongue and mask; I call'd her ugly, old, and old acquaintance, and yet she wou'd not disprove me: but here comes Ranger, let him try what he can do, for since my Mistress is dogged, I'll go sleep alone.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Ranger! 'tis he indeed; I am sorry he is here, but glad I discovered him before I went, yet he must not discover me, lest I should be prevented hereafter, in finding him out, false Ranger.
Aside.
Nay, if they bring fresh force upon us, Madam, 'tis time to quit the Field.
Ex. Lyd. Flip.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: What, play with your quarrey till it fly from you·

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: You frightned it away.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Ha! is not one of those Ladies in mourning?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: All women are so by this light.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But you might easily descern it, don't you know her?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Did you talk with her?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Yes, she's one of your brisk silly Baggages.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
'Tis she, 'tis she, I was afraid I saw her before, let us follow 'em, prithee make haste.
Exeunt.
'Tis Lydia.
Aside.
sp.l: Lydia, my Lady Flippant return at the other door,

Ranger, Dapperwit
, following them at a distance.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: They follow us yet I fear.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: You do not fear it certainly, otherwise, you wou'd not have encourag'd them.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
For heavens sake, Madam, wave your quarrel a little; and let us pass by your Coach, and so on foot to your acquaintance in the old Pell-mell; for I wou'd not be discover'd by the man that came up last to us.
Exeunt.

div.stage:
The Scene changes to
Christina
's Lodging
.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: For Heavens sake undress your self, Madam; they'l not return to night, all people have left the Park an hour agoe.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: What is't a Clock?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: 'Tis past one.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I thought, that time had only stolen from happy Lovers; the Disconsolate have nothing to do but to tell the Clock.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I can only keep account with my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am glad they are not innumerable.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: And truly my undergoing so often your impertinency, is not the least of them.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I am then more glad, Madam, for then they cannot be great, and it is in my power, it seems, to make you in part happy, if I cou'd but hold this villanous tongue of mine, but then let the people of the Town hold their tongues if they will, for I cannot but tell you what they say.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: What do they say?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I am afraid to tell you, now I think on't.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Is it so ill?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, such base unworthy things.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Do they say, I was really Clerimont's Wench as he boasted; and that the ground of the quarrell betwixt Valentine and him, was not Valentines vindication of my honour, but Clerimonts jealousie of him.

sp.speaker: Isa,
sp.p: Worse, worse a thousand times, such villanous things to the utter ruin of your reputation.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, you'l be angry, 'tis the old trick of Lovers to hate their informers, after they have made 'em such.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I will not be angry.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: They say then, since Mr. Valentines flying into France, you are grown mad, have put your self into Mourning, live in a dark room, where you'l see no body, nor take any rest day or night, but rave and talk to your self perpetually.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Now what else?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: But the surest sign of your madness is, they say, because you are desperately resolv'd (in case my Lord Clerimont should dye of his wounds, to Transport your self and Fortune into France, to Mr. Valentine, a man that has not a groat to return you in exchange.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: All this hitherto, is true; now to the rest.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I have no more to tell you, I was sorry, I'm sure, to hear so much of any Lady of mine.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Insupportable insolence.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
This is some revenge for my want of sleep to night; so I hope my old second is come; 'tis seasonable relief.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p:
Unhappy Valentine, cou'dst thou but
Exit. Isabella.
see how soon thy absence, and mis-fortunes have disbanded all thy Friends, and turn'd thy Slaves all Renegades, thou sure wou'dst prize my only faithful heart.

div.stage:
Enter my Lady
Flippant, Lydia, Isabel,
to her
.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Hail faithful Shepherdess; but truly, I had not kept my word with you, in coming back to night, if it had not been for this Lady, who has her intrigues too with the fellows, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Madam, under my Lady Flippants protection, I am confident to beg yours; being just now pursu'd out of the Park, by a relation of mine, by whom it imports me extreamly not to be discover'd; but I fear he is now at the door.
Knocking at the door.
Let me desire you to deny me to him couragiously,
To Isabel
going out
.
for he will hardly believe he can be mistaken in me.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: In such an occasion where impudence is requisite, she will serve you, as faithfully as you can wish, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam, do not upbraid her with her assurance, a qualification that only fits her for a Ladies Service; a fine Woman of the Town, can be no more without a woman that can make an excuse with an assurance, then she can be without a glass certainly.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: She needs no Advocate.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: How can any one alone manage an amorous intrigue; though the Birds are tame, some body must help draw the Net; if 'twere not for a Woman that could make an excuse with assurance, how shou'd we whedle, jilt, trace, discover, countermine, undermine, and blow up the stinking fellows, which is all the pleasure I receive, or design by them; for I never admitted a man to my conversation, but for his punishment certainly.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: No body will doubt that, certainly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Madam, the Centleman will not be mistaken, he says you are here, he saw you come in; he is your Relation, his name's Ranger, and is come to wait upon you home; I had much ado to keep him from coming up.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Madam, for Heavens sake help me, 'tis yet in your power, if but while I retire into your Dining-room,
To Christina.
you will please to personate me, and own your self, for her, he pursu'd out of the Park; you are in Mourning too, and your Stature so much mine, it will not contradict you.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I am sorry, Madam, I must dispute any command of yours; I have made a resolution to see the face of no man, till an unfortunate Friend of mine, now out of the Kingdom, return.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: By that Friend, and by the hopes you have to see him, let me conjure you to keep me from the sight of mine now; Dear Madam, let your charity prevail over your superstition.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: He comes, he comes Madam.

div.stage:
Lydia
withdraws and stands unseen at the door.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Ha! this is no Lydia.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: What unworthy defamer has encouraged you to offer me this insolence.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
She is liker Lydia in her style, then her face; I see I am mistaken, but to tell her I follow'd her for another, were an affront, rather then an excuse; she's a glorious creature.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Tell me, Sir, whence had you reason for this your rude pursuit of me, into my Lodging, my Chamber; why should you follow me?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, because you run away from me.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: That was no sign of an acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You'l pardon me Madam.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Then it seems you mistook me for another, and the night is your excuse, which blots out all distinctions: but now you are satisfyed in your mistake, I hope, you will go seek out your Woman in another place.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Madam, I allow not the excuse you make for me; if I have offended, I will rather be condemned for my love, then pardon'd for my insensibility.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
How's that?
behind.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Though the night had been darker, my heart wou'd not have suffer'd me to follow any one but you; he has been too long acquainted with you, to mistake you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
What means this tenderness; he mistook me for her sure?
behind.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: What says the Gentleman? did you know me then Sir?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Not I, the Devil take me, but I must on now.
Aside.
Cou'd you imagine, Madam, by the innumerable crowd of your admirers, you had left any man free in the Town, or ignorant of the power of your Beauty.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I never saw your face before, that I remember.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Ah Madam! you wou'd never regard you humb'lest Slave; I was till now a modest Lover.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Falsest of men.
behind.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: My woman said, you came to seek a Relation here, not a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I must confess, Madam, I thought you wou'd sooner disprove my dissembled error, then admit my visit; and I was resolv'd to see you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
'Tis clear.
behind.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Indeed, when I follow'd you first out of the Park, I was afraid you might have been a certain Relation of mine, for your Statures and Habits are the same; but when you enter'd here, I was with joy convinc'd: Besides, I would not for the world have given her troublesom love, so much encouragement, to have disturb'd my future addresses to you; for the foolish woman do's perpetually torment me, to make our relation nearer; but never more in vain, then since I have seen you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
How shall I suffer this? 'tis clear he disappointed me to night for her, and made me stay at home, that I might not disappoint him of her company in the Park.
behind.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I am amaz'd! but let me tell you, Sir, if the Lady were here, I wou'd satisfie her, the sight of me shou'd never frustrate her ambitious designs upon her cruel Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
I wish you cou'd satisfie me.
behind.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: If she were here, she wou'd satisfie you, she were not capable of the honour to be taken for you (though in the dark) faith, my Cousin is but a tolerable woman to a man that had not seen you.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Sure to my Plague, this is the first time you ever saw me?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Sure to the Plague of my poor heart, 'tis nor the hundredth time I have seen you; for since the time I saw you first, you have not been at the Park, Play-house, Exchange, or other publick place, but I saw you; for it was my business to watch and follow you.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Pray, when did you see me last at the Park, Play-house, or Exchange.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Some two, three days, or a week ago.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I have not been this month out of this Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
That is to delude me.
behind.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I knew you were mistaken.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You'll pardon a Lovers memory, Madam.

A pox, I have hang'd my self in my own line, one would think, my perpetual ill luck in lying, should break me of the quality; but like a loosing Gamster, I am still for pushing on, till none will trust me.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you run out of one error into a greater, you would excuse the rudeness of your mistake, and intrusion at this hour, into my Lodgings, with your gallantry to me, more unseasonable and offensive.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, I am in Love I see, for I blush, and have not a word to say for my self.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: But, Sir, if you will needs play the Gallant, pray leave my House before Morning, lest you should be seen go hence, to the scandal of my honour.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Rather then that shou'd be, I'll call up the House and Neighbours to bear witness, I bid you be gon.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Since you take a night-visit so ill, Madam, I will never wait upon you again, but by day; I go, that I may hope to return, and for once, I will wish you a good night without me.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p:
Good night, for as long as I live.
Ex. Ranger

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
And good night to my Love, I'm sure.
Behind.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Though I have done you an inconsiderable service, I assure you, Madam, you are not a little oblig'd to me.

Pardon me dear Valentine.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I know not yet, whether I am more oblig'd then injur'd; when I do I assure you, Madam, I shall not be insensible of either.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I fear, Madam, you are as liable to mistakes, as your Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I fear, I am more subject to 'em, it may be for want of sleep, therefore I'll go home.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: My Lady Flippant, good night.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Good night, or rather good morrow, faithful Shepherdess.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: I'll wait of you down.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Your Coach stays yet, I hope.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Certainly.
Ex. Omnes.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I was a faithful Sentinel, no body came out, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: No, no, I hunted upon a wrong scent; I thought I had follow'd a Woman, but found her an Angel.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What is her name?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: That you must tell me; What very fine woman is there lies hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Faith, I know not any, she is I warrant you some fine woman, of a Terms standing or so in the Town; such as seldom appear in publick, but in their Balcones, where they stand so constantly, one would think they had hir'd no other part of the House.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And look like the Pictures, which Painters expose to draw in Customers; but I must know who she is, Vincents Lodging is hard by, I'll go and enquire of him, and lye with him to night; but if he will not let me, I'll lye with you, for my lodging is too far off—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Then I will go before, and expect you at mine.
Ex.

div.stage:
Enter Vincent, Valentine,
in a riding habit, as newly from a Journey.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Your Mistress, dear Valentine, will not be more glad to see you; but my wonder is no less then my joy, that you wou'd return ere you were inform'd Clerimont were out of danger; his Surgeons themselves, have not been assur'd of his recovery, till within these two days.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I fear'd my Mistress, not my Life; my Life I cou'd trust again with my old enemy Fortune; but not longer, my Mistress, in the hands of my greater Enemies, her Relations.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Your fear was in the wrong place then, for though my Lord Clerimont live, he and his Relations, may put you in more danger of your life, then you Mistresses Relations can of loosing her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Wou'd any cou'd secure me her, I wou'd my self secur my life, for I should value it then.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Come, come, her Relations can do you no hurt; I dare swear, If her Mother shou'd but say, your Hat did not cock handsomly, she wou'd never ask her blessing again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prythee leave thy fooling, and tell me, if since my departure, She has given evidences of her love, to clear those doubts I went away with, for as absence is the bane of common and bastard Love; 'tis the vindication of that, which is true and generous.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Nay, if you cou'd ever doubt her love, you deserve to doubt on; for there is no punishment great enough for jealousie, but jealousie.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may remember, I told you before my flight, I had quarrell'd with the defamer of my Mistress, but thought I had kill'd my Rival.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But pray give me now the answer, which the suddenness of your flight deny'd me; how cou'd Clerimont hope to subdue her heart, by the assault of her honour?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pish, it might be the stratagem of a Rival, to make me desist.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: For shame, if 'twere not rather to vindicate her, then satisfie you, I wou'd not tell you, how like a Penelope she has behav'd her self in your absence.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Let me know.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Then know, the next day you went, she put her self into mourning, and—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That might be for Clerimont, thinking him dead, as all the world besides thought.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Still turning the daggers point on your self, hear me out; I say she put her self into mourning for you— loc'kd up her self in her chamber, this month for you— shut out her barking Relations for you— has not seen the Sun, or face of man, since she saw you— thinks, and talks of nothing but you— sends to me daily, to hear of you— and in short (I think) is mad for you— all this I can swear, for I am to her so near a Neighbour, and so inquisitive a friend for you—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Ranger, Sir, is coming up.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What brings him now? he comes to lye with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Who, Ranger?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Yes, pray retire a little, till I send him off, unless you have a mind to have your arrival publish'd to morrow, in the Coffee-houses.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
What, not yet a-bed? your man is laying you to sleep
Valentine
retires to the door behind
.
with Usquebaugh or Brandy, is he not so?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What Punk will not be troubled with you to night, therefore I am, is it not so?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I have been turn'd out of doors indeed just now, by a Woman, but such a Woman, Vincent—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Yes, yes, your women are always such women.—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: A Neighbour of yours, and I'm sure the finest you have.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Prythee do not asperse my Neighbourhood with your acquaintance; 'twould bring a scandal upon an Alley.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, I do not know her, therefore I come to you.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: 'Twas no wonder, she turn'd you out of doors then; and if she had known you, 'twould have been a wonder she had let you stay; but where does she live?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
—
He whispers.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Pish, pish—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: — Does she live there, do you say?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Yes, I observ'd them exactly, that my account from you, might be as exact; do you know who lives there?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Yes, so well, that I know you are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Is she not a young Lady scarce eighteen, of extraordinary beauty, her stature next to low, and in mourning?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
What is this?
Behind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: She is; but if you saw her, you broke in at window.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I chas'd her home from the Park, indeed, taking her for another Lady who had some claim to my heart, 'till she shew'd a better title to't.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Was she at Park then? and have I a new Rival?
Behind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: From the Park did you follow her, do you say? I knew you were mistaken.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I tell you I am not.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: If you are sure, it was that house, it might be perhaps her woman stollen to the Park, unknown to her Lady.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: My acquaintance does usually begin with the Maid first, but now 'twas with the Mistress, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: The Mistress! I tell you, she has not been out of her doors since Valentines flight; she is his Mistress, the great Heiress Christina.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I tell you then again, I followed that Christina from the Park home, where I talk'd with her half an hour, and intend to see her to morrow again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Would she talk with him too?
behind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Christina, do you call her? faith I am sorry she is an Heiress, lest it should bring the scandal of interest, and design of lucre upon my Love.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: No, no, her face and vertues will free you from that censure; but however, 'tis not fairly done to Rival your friend Valentine in his absence; and when he is present, you know 'twil be dangerous, by my Lord Clerimont's example; faith if you have seen her, I would not advise you to attempt it again.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You may be merry, Sir, you are not in Love; your advise I came not for, nor will I for your assistance; good night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Here's your Penelope, the woman that
Ex. Ranger.
had not seen the Sun, nor face of Man, since my departure; for it seems she goes out in the night, when the Sun is absent, and faces are not distinguish'd.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Why, do you believe him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Shou'd I believe you?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: 'Twere more for your interest, and you wou'd be less deceiv'd; if you believe him, you must doubt the chastity of all the fine Women in Town, and five miles about.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.p: His reports of them, will little invallidate his testimony with me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
He spares not the Innocents in Bibs and Aprons (I'le secure
you) he has made (at best) some gross mistake concerning Christina, which to morrow will discover; in the mean time let us go sleep.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I will not hinder you, because I cannot enjoy it my self;
sp.l: Hunger, Revenge, to sleep are petty Foes,

But only Death the jealous Eyes can close.
Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE. I. Crossbites House.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: GGod morrow, Gossip.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Good morrow; but why up so early good Gossip?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
