sp.p: My care and passionate concern for you, and yours, wou'd not let me rest (intruly.)

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: For me and mine?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You know, we have known one another long; I think it be some nine and thirty years since you were marryed.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Nine and thirty years old Mistress? I'de have you to know, I am no far born Child; and if the Register had not been burn'd in the last great fire alas; but my face needs no Register sure: nine and thirty years old said you, Mistress?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I said you had been so long marryed; but, indeed, you bear your years as well as any she in Pepper-Alley.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Nine and thirty, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: This it is; a woman now-adays, had rather you should find her faulty with a man, I warrant you, then discover her age, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Marry and 'tis the greater secret far; tell a Miser he is rich, and a Woman she is old; you will get no money of him, nor kindness of her: to tell me I was nine and thirty (I say no more) 'twas unneighbourly done of you, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: My memory confessess my age, it seems, as much as my face, for I thought—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Pray talk, nor think no more of any ones Age; but say, what brought you hither so early?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: How does my sweet God-daughter? poor wretch.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Well, very well.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Ah sweet Creature; alas, alas, I am sorry for her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why, what has she done to deserve your sorrow, or my reprehension?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
What are they talking of me?
behind.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: In short, she was seen going into the Meeting-house of the Wicked, otherwise called the Play house, hand in hand, with that vile fellow Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Mr. Dapperwit; let me tell you, if 'twere not for Master Dapperwit, we might have liv'd all this Vacation upon Green Cheese, Tripe, and Ox-cheek; if he had it, we should not want it; but poor Gentleman, it often goes hard with him, for he's a Wit..

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: So then, you are the Dog to be fed, while the house is broken up; I say beware, the sweet bits you swallow, will make your daughters belly swell, Mistress; and after all your Junkets, there will be a bone for you to pick, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sure, Master Dapperwit is no such manner of man?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: He is a Wit, you say, and what are Wits? but contemners of Matrons, Seducers, or Defamers of married Women, and Deflourers of helpless Virgins, even in the Streets, upon the very Bulks; Affronters of midnight Magistracy, and Breakers of Windows in a word.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But he is a little-Wit, a modest-wit, and they do no such outragious things, as your great Wits do.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Nay, I dare say, he will not say himself he is a little-Wit, if you ask him.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Nay, I cannot hear this with patience; with your
Aside.
pardon mother, you are as much mistaken, as my God-mother in
Mr. Dapperwit
; for he is as great a Wit as any, and in what he speaks or writes, as happy as any; I can assure you, he contemns all your tearing Wits, in comparison of himself.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Alas, poor young wretch, I cannot blame thee so much as thy mother, for thou art not thy self; his bewitching Madrigals
have charm'd thee into some Heathenish, Imp with a hard name.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nymph, you mean God-mother.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: But you Gossip, know what's what; yesterday, as I told you, a fine Old Alderman of the City, seeing your Daughter in so ill hands as Dapperwits, was Zealously, and in pure Charity, bent upon her redemption; and has sent me to tell you, he will take her into his care, and relieve your necessities, if you think good.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Will he relieve all our necessities?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Mine, as well as my Daughters?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Well fare his heart; d'y here Daughter,
Mrs. Joyner
has satisfy'd me clearly; Dapperwit is a vile fellow, and in short, you must put an end to that scandalous familiarity between you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Leave sweet
Mr. Dapperwit
— Oh furious ingratitude! was not he the man that gave me my first Farrenden Gown, put me out of Worsted Stockings, and plain Handkerchiefs, taught me to dress, talk, and move well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He has taught you to talk indeed; but Huswife, I will not have my pleasure disputed.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Nay, indeed you are too tart with her, poor sweet Soul.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He taught me to rehearse too, wou'd have brought me to the Play-house, where I might have had as good luck as others: I might have had good Cloaths, Plate, Jewels, and things so well about me; that my Neighbours, the little Gentlemens Wives, of Fifteen hundred, or Two thousand pound a year, should have retir'd into the Country, sick of th' envy, of my prosperity and greatness.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: if you follow your mothers counsel, you are like to enjoy all you talk of sooner; then by Dapperwits assistance; a poor wretch that goes on tick for the Paper he writes his Lampoons on; and the very Ale and Coffee that inspires him as they say.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am credibly informed so, indeed, Madam Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Well, I have discharg'd my Conscience; good morrow to you both.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: This is the Cabinet, in which I hide my Jewel, a small house, in an obscure, little, retired street too.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Vulgarly an Alley.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Nay, I hid my Mistress, with as much care, as a Spark of the Town do's his money from his Dun, after a good hand at Play; and nothing but you cou'd have wrought upon me for a sight of her, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: My obligation to you is great; do not lessen it by delays, of the favour you promised.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: But do not censure my honour, for if you had not been in a desperate condition— for as one nail must beat out another, one poyson expel another, one fire draw out another, one fit of drinking cure the sickness of another; so the Surfeit you took last night of Christina's eyes, shall be cured by Lucy's this morning, or as—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, I bar more similitudes.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, in my Mistresses lodging? that were as hard as to bar a young Parson in the Pulpit, the fifth of November, railing at the Church of Rome, or as hard as to put you to bed to Lucy, and defend you touching her, or as—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Or as hard as to make you hold your tongue— I shall not see your Mistress, I see?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Miss Lucy, Miss Lucy—
Knocks at the door, and returns.
the Devil take me, if good men (I say no more) have not been upon their knees to me, to see her, and you at last must obtain it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I do not believe you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: 'Tis such a she, she is beautiful, without affectation, amorous without impertinency, airy, and brisk without impudence, frolick without rudeness; and in a word, the justest creature breathing to her asignation.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You praise her, as if you had a mind to part with her; and yet you resolve, I see, to keep her to your self.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Keep her, poor Creature, she cannot leave me; and rather then leave her, I wou'd leave writing Lampoons or Sonnets almost.

sp.speaker: Ran·
sp.p: Well, I'le leave you with her then.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, will you go without seeing her?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Rather then stay without seeing her.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you shall see her; but let me perish if I have not been offered a hundred Guinnies, for a sight of her; by— I say no more.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I understand you now; if the favour be to be
Aside.
purchased, then I'le bid all I have about me for't.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Fye fye,
Mr. Ranger
, you are pleasant i'faith; do you think I would sell the sight of my rarity? like those Gentlemen who hang out Flags at Charing-cross, or like—

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Nay, then i'm gone again.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, you take it ill I refuse your money? rather then that shou'd be, give us it; but take notice I will borrow it; now I think on't, Lucy wants a Gown, and some Knacks.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: But I must pay it you again; I will not take it, unless you engage your honour, I shall pay it you again.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You must pardon me; I will not engage my honour for such a trifle; go fetch her out.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Well, she's a ravishing Creature, such eyes, and lips,
Mr. Ranger
.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Prethee go.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Such neck and breasts, Mr. Ranger.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Again, prethee go.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Such, feet, legs, and thighs,
Mr. Ranger
.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Prethee let me see 'em.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And a mouth no bigger then your Ring; I need say no more.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Wou'd thou wer't never to speak again.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And then so neat, so sweet a Creature in bed, that to my knowledge, she do's not change her Sheets in half a year.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I thank you for that allay to my impatience.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Miss Lucy, Miss Lucy, Miss.
Knocking at the dore.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Will she not open?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I am afraid, my prety Miss is not stirring, and therefore will not admit us.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Fye, Fye, a quibble next your stomach in a morning; what if she shou'd hear us, wou'd you lose a Mistress for a quible? that's more then I cou'd do, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Is she not gone her walk to Lambs Conduit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: She is within, I hear her.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But she will not hear you; she's as deaf, as if you were a Dun or a Constable.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Pish, give her but leave to gape, rub her eyes, and put on her day-Pinner; the long patch under the left eye; awaken the Roses on her cheeks, with some Spanish wool, and warrant her breath with some Lemmon Peil; the dore flies off of the hindges, and she into my arms; she knows there is as much Artifice to keep a victory, as to gain it; and 'tis a sign she values the conquest of my heart.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I thought her beauty had not stood in need of Art.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Beauty's a Coward, still without the help of Art, and may have the fortune of a Conquest, but cannot keep it; Beauty and Art can no more be asunder, then Love and Honour.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Or to speak more like your self, wit and judgment.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Don't you hear the dore wag yet?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Miss, Miss, 'tis your slave that calls; come, all this tricking for him; lend me your Comb, Mr. Ranger.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: No, I am to be preferred to day, you are to set me off; you are in possession; I will not lend you arms to keep me out—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: A Pox, don't let me be ungrateful; if she has smugg'd her self up for me, let me Prune, and Flounce my Perruque a little for her; there's ne're a young fellow in the Town but will do as much, for a meer stranger in the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: A Wits Wig, has the priviledge of being uncomb'd in the very Play-house, or in the presence—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: But not in the presence of his Mistress; 'tis a greater neglect of her then himself; pray lend me your Comb.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I wou'd not have men of Wit, and Courage, make use of every Fops mean Arts, to keep, or gain a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: But don't you see every day, though a man have ne're so much Wit and Courage, his Mistress will revolt to those Fops that wear, and Comb Peruques well; i'le break off the bargain, and will not receive you, my Partner.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Therefore you see I am setting
Combs his Perruque.
up for my self.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: She comes, she comes, pray, your Comb.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Bargain, what are you offering us to sale?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
A Pox, is't she? here take your Comb again then.
Returns the Comb.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Wou'd you sell us? 'tis like you y'fads.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Sell thee, where shou'd we find a Chapman? go prithee mother, call out my dear Miss Lucy▪

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your Miss Lucy; I do not wonder you have the Conscience to bargain for us behind our backs, since you have the impudence to claim a propriety in us, to my face.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: How's this Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Come, come, this Gentleman will not think the worse of a Woman, for my acquaintance with her; he has seen me bring your Daughter to the Leur with a Chiney Orange, from one side of the Play-house to the other.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I wou'd have the Gentleman, and you to know, my Daughter is a Girl of reputation, though she has been seen in your company; but is now so sensible of her past danger, that she is resolv'd never more to venture her Pitcher to the Well, as they say.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: How's that Widow? I wonder at your new confidence.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I wonder at your old impudence, that where you have had so frequent repulses, you shou'd provoke another, and bring your Friend here to witness your disgrace.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Hark you Widow a little.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What, you have Mortgaged my Daughter to that Centleman; and now wou'd offer me a snip to joyn in the security.

sp.speaker: Dap.
Cros.
sp.p: She shall not, she will not come to you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Till I hear it from her own mouth, I cannot believe it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You shall hear her say't through the dore.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I shall doubt it, unless she say it to my face.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Shall we be troubled with you no more then?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: If she command my death, I cannot dis-obey her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Come out Child.
Lucy
(holding down her head) to them.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Your Servant dearest Miss, can you have?—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Let me ask her.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: No, I'le ask her.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I'le throw up Cross or Pile who shall ask her.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Can you have the heart to say, you will never more break a Cheese-cake with me, at New Spring-garden, the Neat-house, or Chelsey; never more sit in my lap at a New Play, never more wear a Suit of Knots of my choice; and last of all, never more pass away an afternoon with me again, in the Green Garret? in— do not forget the Green Garret.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wish I had never seen the Green Garret; Demm the Green Garret.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Demm the Green Garret, you are strangely alter'd.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Tis you are alter'd.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: You have refus'd Colby's Mulberry Garden, and the French-houses, for the Green Garret; and a little something in the Green Garret, pleas'd you more then the best Treat the other places cou'd yield; and can you of a sudden quit the Green Garret?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Since you have a design to Pawn me for the Rent, 'tis time to remove my Goods.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Thou art extremely mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Besides, I have heard such strange things of you this morning—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What things?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I blush to speak 'em.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I know my Innocence, therefore take my charge as a favour; what have I done?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Then know vile Wit, my mother has confess'd just now, thou wer't false to me, to her too certain knowledge; and hast forc'd even her to be false to me too.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Faults in drink, Lucy, when we are not our selves, shou'd not condemn us.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And now to let me out to hire like Hackney; I tell you my own dear mother shall bargain for me no more; there are as little as I can bargain for themselves now-adays, as well as properer women.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Whispering all this while; beware of his snares again, come away Child.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Sweet, dear, Miss.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
Bargain for me; you have reckon'd without your Hostess, as they say, bargain for me, bargain for me.
Exit. Lucy.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I must return then, to treat with you.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Treat me no treatings, but take a word for all; you shall no more dishonour my Daughter, nor molest my Lodgings, as you have done at all hours.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Do you intend to change 'em, then, to Bridewel, or Longs powdering-Tub.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: No, to a Bailifs house, and then you'll be so civil, I presume, as not to trouble us.

sp.speaker: Ran,
sp.p: Here, will you have my Comb again, Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: A pox, I think women take inconstancy from me, worse then from any man breathing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Pray, Sir, forget me, before you write your next Lampoon.
Ex. Cros.

div.stage:
Sir Simon Addleplot
in the dress of a Clark. To
Ranger and Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Have I found you? have I found you, in your by-walks, faith and troth? I am almost out of breath in following you; Gentlemen when they get into an Alley, walk so fast; as if they had more earnest business there, then in the broad streets.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
How came this Sot hither? Fortune has sent him to ease my choler.
Aside.

You impudent Rascal, who are you? that dare intrude thus on us.
Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Don't you know me, Dapperwit? sure you know me.
Softly.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Wilt thou dishonour me with thy acquaintance too? thou rascally, insolent, pen and ink-man.
Strikes him again.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, oh sure, you know me, pray know me.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
By thy sawcy familiarity, thou shou'dst be a Marker at
a Tennis-court, a Barber, or a Slave that fills Coffee.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
What art thou?
Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, I must not discover my self to Ranger, for a kick or two; oh, pray hold, Sir, by that you will know me.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: How, Sir Simon!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Mum, mum, make no excuses man, I wou'd not Ranger shou'd have known me for five hundred— kicks.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Your disguise is so natural, I protest, it will excuse me.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I know that, prythee make no excuses, I say; no ceremony between thee and I man; read the Letter.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, you have not open'd it?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Prythee don't be angry, the Seal is a little crack'd; for I cou'd not help kissing Mrs. Martha's Letter, the word is, now or never, her Father she finds will be abroad all this day, and she longs to see your friend, Sir
Simon Addleplot
: faith, 'tis a prety jest; While I am with her, and praising my self to her, at no ordinary rate; let thee and I alone, at an intrigue.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Tell her, I will not fail to meet her, at the place, and time, have a care of your charge; and manage your business like your self, for your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
The gaining Gripes Daughter, will make me support the loss of this young Jilt here.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: What fellow's that?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: A Servant, to a Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Methinks, he something resembles our acquaintance, Sir Simon, but it is no complement to tell him so; for that Knight, is the most egregious Coxcomb, that ever plaid with Ladies Fan.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
So; thanks to my disguise, I know my Enemies.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: The most incorrigible Ass, beyond the reproof of a kicking Rival, or a frowning Mistress; but if it be possible, thou dost use him worse, then his Mistress, or Rival can; thou dost make such a Culley of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Do's he think so too?—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Go friend, go about your business,
Ex. Sir.
Simon.
a pox, you wou'd spoil all, just in the critical time of projection; he brings me here a Summons from his Mistress, to meet her in the evening; will you come to my Wedding?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Don't speak so loud, you'll break poor Lucies heart; poor creature, she cannot leave you, and rather then leave her, you shou'd leave writing of Lampoons, or Sonnets— almost.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Come, let her go, ungrateful baggage; but now you talk of Sonnets; I am no living Wit, if her love has not cost me two thousand Couplets at least.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But, what wou'd you give now, for a new Satyr against women, ready made; 'twou'd be as convenient to buy, Satyrs against women, ready made, as it is to buy Crevats ready ty'd.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Or as—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Hay, come away, come away, Mr. or as—
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Peace, Plenty, and Pastime be within these Walls.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: 'Tis a small House you see, and mean Furniture, for no Gallants are suffer'd to come hither; she might have had ere now, as good lodgings, as any in Town; her Moreclack-Hangings, great Glasses, Cabinets, China embroider'd Beds, Persia Carpets, Gold-plate, and the like, if she would have put her self forward; but your Worship may please, to make 'em remove to a place, fit to receive one of your Worships quality; for this is a little scandalous in truly.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, no, I like it well enough, I am not dainty; besides privacy, privacy, Mrs. Joyner, I love privacy, in opposition to the Wicked, who hate it?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
What do you look for, Sir?
Looks about.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Walls have ears, Walls have ears; but besides, I look for a private place to retire to, in time of need; oh her's one convenient.
Turns up a Hanging, and discovers the slender provisions of the Family.

sp.speaker: Joyn·
sp.p: But you see poor innocent Souls, to what use they put it, not to hide Gallants.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Temperance is the nurse of Chastity.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: But your Worship may please to mend their fare; and when you come, may make them entertain you, better then, you see, they do themselves.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, I am not dainty, as I told you; I abominate Entertainments; no Entertainments, pray Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
No.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: There can be no entertainment to me, more Luscious and Savoury, then the communion with that little Gentlewoman; will you call her out, I fast till I see her.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: But intruly your Worship, we shou'd have brought a bottle or two of Rhenish, and some Naples Bisket, to have entertain'd the young Gentlewoman; 'tis the mode for Lovers to Treat their Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Modes, I tell you
Mrs. Joyner
, I hate Modes and Forms.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You must send for something to entertain her with.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Again entertaining; we will be to each other a Feast.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I shall be asham'd, intruly your Worship; besides, the young Gentlewoman will despise you.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I shall content her, I warrant you, leave it to me.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
I am sure you will not content me, if you will not content her; 'tis as impossible for a man to love, and be a miser, as to love and be wise, as they say.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: While you talk of Treats, you starve my eyes; I long to see the fair One; fetch her hither.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I am asham'd she shou'd find me so abominable a lyar; I have so prays'd you to her, and above all your Vertues, your Liberality; which is so great a Vertue, that it often excuses Youth, Beauty, Courage, Wit, or any thing.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pish, Pish, 'tis the vertue of Fools, every Fool can have it.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: And will your worship want it then? I told her—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Why wou'd you tell her any thing of me? you know I am a modest man; but come, if you will have me as extravagant as the wicked; take that, and fetch us a Treat, as you call it.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Upon my life a Groat, what will this purchase?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Two Black Pots of Ale, and a Cake, at the next Cellar;
come, the Wine has Arsenick in't.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Well, I am mistaken, and my hopes are abus'd; I never knew any man so mortify'd a Miser, that he would deny his Letchery any thing; I must be even with thee then another way.
Goes out.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: These useful old Women are more exorbitant, and craving in their desires, then the young ones in theirs; these Prodigals in white Peruques, spoil 'em both; and that's the reason when the Squires come under my cluchess; I make 'em pay for their folly and mine, and 'tis but Conscience: Oh here comes the fair One at last.

div.stage:
Enter Joyner
leading in
Lucy,
who hangs backward as she enters.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh Lord, there's a man God-mother!

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Come in Child, thou art so bashful—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: My mother is from home too, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: If she were here, she'd teach you better manners.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'm afraid she'd be angry.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: To see you so much an Ass; come along I say.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Nay, speak to her gently; if you won't, I will.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pretty Innocent, there is I see, one left yet of her age; what hap have I! sweet, little Gentlewoman, come and sit down by me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I am better bred, I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You must sit down by me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I'd rather stand, if you please.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: To please me, you must sit, Sweetest.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Not before my God-mother, sure.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Wonderment of Innocence!

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: A poor bashful Girl, Sir; I'm sorry she is not better taught.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I am glad she is not taught; I'le teach her my self.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Are you a Dancing-master then, Sir? but if I shou'd be dull, and not move as you wou'd have me, you wou'd not beat me, Sir, I hope?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Beat thee, hony Suckle; I'le use thee thus, and thus,
and thus; ah, Mrs. Joyner, prethee go fetch our Treat now.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: A Treat of a Groat, I will not wag.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Why don't you go? here, take more money, and fetch what you will; take here, half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: What will half a Crown do?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Take a Crown then, an Angel, a Piece; be gone.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: A Treat only will not serve my turn, I must buy the poor Wretch there some toys.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What toys? what? speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Pendents, Neck-laces, Fans, Ribbonds, Poynts, Laces, Stockings, Gloves—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold, before it comes to a Gown.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Sir, indeed she wants a Gown, for she has but that one to her back; for your own sake you should give her a new Gown; for variety of Dresses, rouses desire, and makes an old Mistress seem every day a new one.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: For that reason she shall have no new Gown; for I am naturally constant, and as I am still the same, I love she shou'd be still the same; but here take half a piece for the other things.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Half a Piece—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Prethee be gone, take t'other Piece then; two Pieces, three Pieces, five; here, 'tis all I have.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I must have the Broad-Seal Ring too, or I stir not.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: Insatiable Woman, will you have that too?
Prethee spare me that, 'twas my Grandfathers.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
That's false, he had ne're a Coat; so now I go; this is but a violent fit, and will not hold.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, whither do you go God-mother? will you leave me alone?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: The Gentleman will not hurt you; you may venture your self with him alone.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
I think I may, God-mother; what, will
Ex. Joyner.
you lock me in, Sir? don't lock me in, Sir.

div.stage: Fumbling at the dore, locks it.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: 'Tis a private lesson, I must teach you fair.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I don't see your Fidle, Sir, where is your little Kitt?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: I'le shew it thee presently Sweetest;

Come my dearest.
Takes her in his arms.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p:
What do you mean, Sir? don't hurt me, Sir, will you— Oh, Oh, you will kill me! murder, murder, oh, oh— help, help, oh—
Crys out.

div.stage:
The dore broke open; Enter
Crossbite,
and two men in Aprons, her Landlord, and his Prentice.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What, murder my Daughter Villain?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I wish he had murder'd me, oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why wou'd you go out, and leave me alone? unfortunate woman that I am.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
How now, what will this end in?
Aside.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Who brought him in?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: That Witch, that Treacherous false Woman, my God-mother, who has betray'd me, sold me to his lust; oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Have you ravish'd my Daughter then, you old Goat? ravish'd my Daughter, ravish'd my Daughter, speak Villain.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: By yea, and by nay, no such matter.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
A canting Rogue too; take notice Landlord, he has ravish'd my Daughter, you see her all in tears and distraction; and see there the wicked Engine of the
Pointing to the Chair.
filthy execution; Jeremy, call up my Neighbours, and the Constable, false Villain, thou shalt dye for't.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Hold, hold; nay, I am caught.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Go, go, make haste—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Poor wretch, go quickly.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, hold; thou young Spawn of the old Serpent; Wicked, as I thought thee Innocent; wilt thou say I wou'd have ravish'd thee?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I will swear you did ravish me.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
I thought so, Treacherous Eve, then I am gone, I must shift as well as I can.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Will none of you call up the Neighbours, and the Authority of the Alley?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hold, I'le give you Twenty Mark among you, to let me go.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Villain, nothing shall buy thy life.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: But stay, Mrs. Crossbite, let me talk with you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I am your Friend; in a word, I have appeas'd her, and she shall be contented with a little sum.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: What is it? what is it?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: But five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: But five hundred pound; hang me then, hang me rather.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: You will say I have been your friend.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: The Constable, and Neighbors are coming.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
How, how; will you not take a hundred? pray use conscience in your ways.
Kneels to
Crossbite.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I scorn your money, I will not take a thousand.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
Land.
sp.p: The instruments are drawing in the other room, if you please to go thither.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Indeed, now I consider; a Portion will do my Daughter more good, then his death; that wou'd but publish her shame; money will cover it,
probatum est
, as they say— let me tell you, Sir, 'tis a charitable thing to give a young Maid a Portion.
Exeunt Omnes.

div.stage:
The Scene changes to
Lydias Lodging.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Tis as hard for a woman to conceal her indignation from her apostate Lover, as to conceal her Love from her faithful servant.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Or almost as hard as it is, for the prating fellows now adays, to conceal the favours of obliging Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
If Ranger shou'd come up, (I saw him just now in the street) the discovery of my anger to him now, wou'd be as
mean as the discovery of my love to him before.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Though I did so mean a thing, as to love a fellow, I wou'd not do so mean a thing, as to confess it, certainly, by my trouble to part with him; If I confest Love, it should be before they left me.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: So you wou'd deserve to be left, before you were; but cou'd you ever do so mean a thing, as to confess love to any?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Yes; but I never did so mean a thing, as really to love any?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: You had once a Husband.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Fye, Madam, do you think me so ill bred, as to love a Husband.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: You had a Widows heart, before you were a Widow I see.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I shou'd rather make an adventure of my honour, with a Gallant, for a Gown, a new Coach, a Neck-lase, then clap my Husbands cheeks for them, or sit in his lap; I shou'd be as asham'd to be caught in such a posture, with a Husband, as a brisk well bred of the Town, wou'd be, to be caught on his knees at prayers, unless to his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Mr. Ranger, 'twas obligingly done of you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Indeed Cousin, I had kept my promise with you, last night, but this Gentleman knows—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: You mistake me, but you shall not lessen any favour you do me; you are going to excuse your not coming to me last night, when I take it as a particular obligation, that though you threatned me with a visit, upon consideration you were so civil, as not to trouble me.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
This is an unlucky morning with me; here's my eternal persecution, the Widow Flippant.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: What, Mr. Dapperwit!

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Indeed Cousin, besides my business, another cause, I did not wait on you, was, my apprehension, you were gone to the Park, notwithstanding your promise to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Therefore, you went to the Park, to visit me there, notwithstanding your promise to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Who, I at the Park? when I had promis'd to wait upon you at your lodging; but were you at the Park, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Who, I at the Park? when I had promis'd to wait for you at home; I was no more at the Park then you were; were you at the Park?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: The Park had been a dismal desart to me, notwithstanding all the good company in't; if I had wanted yours.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Because it has been the constant endeavour of men, to keep women ignorant, they think us so, but 'tis that encreases our inquisitiveness, and makes us know them ignorant, as false; he is as impudent a dissembler as the widow Flippant, who is making her importunate addresses, in vain, for ought I see.
Aside.

div.stage:
Flippant driving Dapperwit
from one side of the Stage, to the other.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Dear, Mr. Dapperwit, merciful, Mr. Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Unmerciful, Lady Flippant.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Will you be satisfied?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Won't you be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
That a Wit shou'd be jealous! that a Wit shou'd be jealous! there's never a brisk young fellow in the Town, though no Wit Heaven knows; but thinks too well of himself, to think ill of his Wife, or Mistress; now that a Wit shou'd lessen his opinion of himself, for shame.
Aside to
Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
I promis'd to bring you off, but I find it enough to shift for my self—
Softly apart to
Ranger.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: What, out of breath, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I have been defending our cause, Madam; I have beat him out of the Pit; I do so mumble these prating, censorious fellows, they call Wits, when I meet with them.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Her Ladyship indeed, is the only thing in Petty-coats, I dread, 'twas well for me there was company in the Room; for I dare no more venture my self with her alone, then a Culley that has been bit, dares venture himself in a Tavern, with an old Rook.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I am the revenger of our Sex, certainly.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: And the most insatiable one, I ever knew, Madam; I dare not stand your fury longer; Mr. Ranger, I will go before and make a new appointment, with your friends that exppect you at dinner, at the French-house, 'tis fit business, still wait on Love.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Do so— but now I think on't, Sir Thomas goes out of Town this afternoon, and I shall not see him here again these three months.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Nay, pray take him with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Flyp.
sp.p:
No, Sir, you shall not take the Gentleman from his Mistress:
do not go yet, sweet Mr. Dapperwit.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Take him with you, Sir; I suppose his business may be there, to borrow, or win, mony, and I ought not to be his hinderance; for when he has none, he has his desperate designs upon that little I have; for want of mony, makes as devout Lovers as Christians.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, he offers you no less security, then his liberty.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: His liberty, as poor a pawn to take up mony on, as honour; he is like the desperate Banke-routs of this age, who if they can get peoples fortunes into their hands, care not though they spend them in Goale, all their lives.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: And the poor crediting Ladies, when they have parted with their mony, must be contented with a pitiful composition or starve for all them.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But Widows are commonly so wise, as to be sure their men are solvable, before they trust 'em.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Can you blame 'em; I declare, I will trust no man, pray do not take it ill, Gentlemen; Quacks in their Bills, and Poets in the titles of their Plays, do not more disapoint us, then Gallants with their promises; but I trust none.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Nay, she's a very Jew in that particular; to my knowledg, shee'll know her man, over and over again, before she trust him.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Well, my dearest Cousin, good morrow; when I stay from you, so long again, blame me to purpose, and be extreamly angry; for nothing can make me amends for the loss of your company, but your reprehension of my absence; I'll take such a chiding, as kindly, as Russian Wives, do beating.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: If you were my Husband, I cou'd not take your absence more kindly, then I do.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: And if you were my wife, I wou'd trust you as much out of my sight, as I cou'd, to shew my opinion of your virtue.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
A well-bred Gentleman, I warrant; will you go then cruel Mr. Dapperwit?
Ex. Ranger and Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Have I not dissembled well, Leonor?
Apart.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But, Madam, to what purpose; why do you not put him to his tryal, and see what he can say for himself?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I am afraid lest my proofs, and his guilt, shou'd make him desperate, and so contemn that pardon, which he cou'd not hope for.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis unjust to condemn him, before you hear him.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I will reprieve him till I have more evidence.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How will you get it?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I will write him a Letter in Christina's name, desiring to meet him; when I shall soon discover, if his love to her be of a longer standing, then since last night; and if it be not, I will not longer trust him with the vanity, to think she gave him the occasion, to follow her home from the Park; so will at once disabuse him and my self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What care the jealous take in making sure of ills, which they, but in imagination, cannot undergo.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.l: Misfortunes are least dreadful, when most near.

'Tis less to undergo the ill, then fear.
Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE. I. Gripe's House.
div.stage:
Enter Mrs. Joyner, and Gripe
in a Blew Gown and Night Cap.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: WHat not well your Worship? this it is, you will be laying out your self beyond your strength; you have taken a Surfeit of the little Gentlewoman, I find; indeed, you shou'd not have been so immoderate in your embraces, your Worship is something in years, intruly.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Graceless, Perfidious Woman, what mak'st thou here? art thou not afraid to be us'd like an Informer, since thou hast
made me pay thee for betraying me?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Betray your Worship, what do you mean? I an Informer, I scorn your words.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Woman, I say again, thou art as Treacherous as an Informer, and more unreasonable; for he lets us have something for our money, before he disturbs us.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Your money, I'me sure, was laid out faithfully; and I went away because I wou'd not disturb you.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I had not grudg'd you the money I gave you, but the five hundred pound; the five hundred pound, inconscionable false woman; the five hundred pound; you cheated, trappand, rob'd me of the five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I cheat you, I rob you; well, remember what you say, you shall answer it before Mr. Double-Cap, and the best of—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh impudent woman, speak softly!

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I will not speak softly, for innocence is loud, as well as bare-fac'd; is this your return, after you have made me a meer drudge to your filthy lusts?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Speak softly, my Sister, Daughter and Servants will hear.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I wou'd have witnesses, to take notice, that you blast my good name, which was as white as a Tulip, and as sweet as the head of your Cane; before you wrought me to the carrying on the work of your fleshly carnal seekings.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Softly, softly, they are coming in.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: What's the matter Brother?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing Sister, only the Godly woman is fallen into a fit of Zeal, against the enormous transgressions of the Age; go, go, you do not love to hear vanity reprov'd; pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Pray stay, Madam, that you may know—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Hold, hold, here are five Guinies for thee, pray say nothing.
Aside. To
Joyner.

Sister, pray be gone, I say; wou'd you prejudice your own reputation, to injure mine?
Ex. Flippant and Martha.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Wou'd you prejudice your own Soul to wrong my repute, intruly?
She seems to weep.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pray have me in excuse; indeed, I thought, you had a share of the five hundred pound, because you took away my Seal Ring, which they made me send, together, with a Note to my Cash-keeper for five hundred pound; besides, I thought none, but you, knew it was my wonted token to send for money by.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: 'Twas unlucky I shou'd forget it, and leave it on the Table; but, oh the Harlotry! did she make that use of it then? 'twas no wonder you did not stay till I came back.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I stay'd till the money released me.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Have they the money then? five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Too certain.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: They told me not a word of it; and have you no way to retrive it?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Not any.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
Gripe.
sp.p: I will not for five hundred pound, publish my transgression my self; lest I shou'd be thought to glory in't; though, I must confess, 'twould tempt a man to conform to publick praying and sinning; since 'tis so chargeable to pray, and sin in private.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: But are you resolv'd to give off, a loser?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: How shall I help it?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Nay, I'le see you shall have, what the young jade has; for your money, i'le make 'um use some conscience however; take a mans money for nothing?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Thou say'st honestly indeed; and shall I have my penniworths out of the little Gentlewoman for all this?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I'le be engag'd body for body for her, and you shall take the forfeiture on me else.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, no, I'le rather take your word, Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Go in and dress your self Smug, and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No man breathing would give off a loser, as she says.

div.stage:
Enter Sir
Simon Addleplot,
sitting at a Desk writing as a Clerk, my Lady
Flippant
jogging him
.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis a Lords Mortgage, and therefore requires the more hast; pray do not jog me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Dull Rascal.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: They cannot stay for money, as other Folks; if you will not let me make an end on't, I shall loose my expedition fee.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
There are some Clerks wou'd have understood me before this.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, pray be quiet, Madam; if you squeeze me so to the wall, I cannot write.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
'Tis much for the honour of the Gentlemen of this Age, that we Persons of Quality are forc'd to descend to the importuning of a Clerk, a Butler, Coachman, or Footman; while the Rogues are as dull of apprehension too, as an unfledg'd Country Squire, amongst his Mothers Maids.
Aside.
Jogs him again.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Again, Let me tell you, Madam, familiarity breeds contempt; you'l never leave, till you have made me sawcy.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I wou'd I cou'd see that.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I vow and swear then, get you gone; or i'le add a black patch, or two, to those on your face.

I shall have no time to get Mrs. Martha out, for her.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Will you, Sir, will you?
Jogs him again.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.l: I must have a plot for her, she is a coy woman.

Aside.
I vow and swear if you pass this Creviss,
I'le kiss you in plain English.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I wou'd I cou'd see that, do you defie me?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
How's this? I vow and swear, she kisses as tamely as Mrs. Ticklish, and with her mouth open too.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I thought you wou'd have been asham'd, to have done so to your Masters own Sister.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I hope you'l be quiet now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Nay, I'le be reveng'd of you sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
If you come again, I shall do more to you then that; I'le persue my plot, and try if she be honest.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
You do more to me then that; nay, if you'l do more to me, then that—
She throws down his Ink, and runs out, he follows her.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I must visit my young Clyants in the mean time.

div.stage:
Sir Simon
returns holding up his hands
.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Lord, who wou'd have thought it?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: What aile you, Sir Simon?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I have made such a discovery, Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Such an one, that makes me at once glad, and sorry; I am sorry my Lady Flippant is nought, but i'me glad I know it; thanks still to my disguise.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Fye, fye.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, this hand can tell—

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: But how!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: She threw down my Ink glass, and ran away into the next room; I follow'd her, and in revenge, threw her down upon the bed; but in short, all that I cou'd do to her, wou'd not make her squeek.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: She was out of breath man, she was out of breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Ah, Mrs Joyner, say no more, say no more of that.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: You rude, unmannerly Rascal.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: You see she complains now.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
I know why, Mrs. Joyner, I know why.
Apart.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I'le have you turn'd out of the house, you are not fit for my brothers service.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Not for yours, you mean, Madam.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I'le go and acquaint my Brother—

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Hold, hold, Madam, speak not so loud, 'tis Sir
Simon Addleplot
, your Lover, who has taken this disguise on purpose to be near you; and to watch, and supplant his Rivals.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
What a beast was I, I cou'd not discover it, you have undone me; why wou'd you not tell me sooner of it.
Aside to
Joyner.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I thought he had been discernable enough.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: I protest I knew him not; for I must confess to you, my eyes are none of the best, since I have us'd the last new wash of Mercury water; what will he think of me?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Let me alone with him; come, come, did you think you cou'd disguise your self from my Ladies knowledg; she knew you man, or else you had ne're had those liberties; alas, poor Lady, she cannot resist you.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: 'Tis my weakness.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: How's this? but here comes my Master.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come, Mrs. Joyner, are you ready to go?

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: I am ever ready when your Worship commands.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Brother, if you go to to'ther end of the Town, you'l set me down near the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: The Play-house, do you think I will be seen near the Play-house?

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
You shall set me down in Lincolus-Inn-Fields then, for I have earnest business there; (When I come home again, I'le laugh at you soundly, Sir Simon.)
Apart.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Has Joyner betray'd me then? 'tis time to look to my hits.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Martha, be sure you stay within now; if you go out, you shall never come into my dores again.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: No, I will not, Sir; I'le ne're come into your dores again, if once I shou'd go out.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
'Tis well said. Girl.
Ex. Gripe, Joyner, Flip.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: 'Twas prettily said, I understand you, they are dull, and have no intrigue in 'em; but dear, sweet Mrs. Martha, 'tis time we were gone, you have stole away your Scarfs, and Hood from your Maid, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Nay, I am ready, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Come, come, Sir
Simon Addleplot
, poor Gentleman, is an impatient man to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Well, my venture is great, I'me sure, for a man I know not; but pray Jonas do not deceive me; is he so fine a Gentleman, as you say he is?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pish, pish, he is the— Gentleman of the Town faith, and troth.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: But may I take your word Jonas?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis not my word, 'tis the word of all the Town.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Excuse me, Jonas, for that; I never heard any speak well of him, but Mr. Dapperwit, and you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: That's because he has been a Rival to all men, and a Gallant to all Ladies; Rivals, and deserted Mistresses, never speak well of a man.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Has he been so general in his Amours, his kindness is not to be vallu'd then?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: The more by you, because 'tis for you he deserts all the rest, faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You plead better for him, then he cou'd for himself; I believe, for indeed they say, he is no better then an Ideot.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Then believe me, Madam, for no body knows him better then I; he has as much Wit, Courage, and as good a Meen to the full, as I have; he an Ideot?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: The common Gull, so perspicuous a Fop, the women find him out, for none of 'em will marry him.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: You may see now, how he and you are abus'd; for that he is not Married, is a sign of his Wit; and for being perspicuous, 'tis false, he is as mysterious as a new Parliament man, or a young States-man, newly taken from a Coffee-house, or Tennis-court.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: But is it a sign of his Wit because he is not Married?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, your Women of the Town ravish your Fops; there's not one about the Town unmarryed, that has any thing.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: It may be then he has spent his Estate.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.l:
How unluckily guess'd.
Aside.
If he had, he has a head, can retrieve it again.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Besides, they say, he has had the modish distemper.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: He can cure it with the best French Chyrurgion in Town.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Has his practice, on himself, been so much?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.l: Come, come.
Fame, like deserted Jilt, does still belye men,
Who doubts her man, must be advis'd by Hymen.

For he knows best of any, how to try men.
Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene, The Old Pell Mell.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Now the Lucy's have renounc'd us; hey for the Christina's, she cannot use me worse, then your honourable Mistress did you.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
A Pox, some young Heir, or another, has promis'd her
Marriage; there are so many Fools in the world, 'tis impossible for a man of Wit to keep his Wench, from being a Lady, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But have you no other acquaintance that sticks to her vocation, in spight of temptations of honour, or filthy lucre; I declare, I make honourable Love, meerly out of necessity; as your Rooks play on the square, rather then not play at all.

div.stage:
To them
Leonore, Lydias
woman mask'd, with a Letter in her hand.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Come, the Devil will not lose a Gamester; here's ready money for you, push freely.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Thou'rt as well met, as if by assignation.
To her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And you are as well met, as if you were the man I look'd for.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Kind Rogue—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Come, I am thy Prisoner, (without more words) shew but thy warrant.
Goes to pull off her Mask.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
You mistake, Sir, here is my Pass.
Gives him the Letter.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
A Letter, and directed to me.
Reads.
Christina! I am amaz'd! what is't a Clock Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: It wants not half an hour of eight.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Go then back, my pretty Herauld,
To the Maid.
and tell my fair Enemy, the service she designs my man, is only fit for my Friend here; of whose Faith and Honour, she may be secure of; he shall, immediately, go wait for her at St. James's Gate; whilst I go to prepare a place for our ran-counter, and my self to dye at her feet:
Ex. Leonore.
Dapperwit, dear Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What lucky Surprisal's this?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Prethee ask no questions, till I have more leisure, and
less astonishment; I know, you will not deny to be an instrument in my happiness.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: No, let me perish, I take as much pleasure to bring Lovers together, as an old Woman, that as a Bankrupt Gamester loves to look on, though he has no advantage by the play; or as a Bully that fights not himself, yet takes pleasure to set people together by the ears; or as—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: S'death, is this a time for similitudes?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: You have made me miscarry of a good thought, now let me perish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Go presently to St. James's gate, where you are to expect the coming of a Lady, ('tis Christina) accompany'd by that woman you saw ev'n now; she will permit you to put her into a Chair, and then conduct her to my lodging, while I go before to remove some Spies, and prepare it for her reception.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Your lodging; had you not better carry her to Vincent's, 'tis hard by, and there a vizard Mask, has as free egress, and regress, as at the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Faith, though it be not very prudent, yet she shall come thither in my vindication; for he wou'd not believe I had seen her last night.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: To have a fine woman, and not tell on't, as you say, Mr. Ranger—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Go, and bring her to Vincent's lodging, there I'le expect you.
Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: This is the door, Madam, here Mr. Vincent lodges.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, we will pass it by, lest the people of our lodging shou'd watch us; but if he shou'd not be here now.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Who, Mr. Valentine, Madam? I warrant you, my intelligencer dares not fail me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Did he come last night, said he?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Last night late.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p:
And not see me yet; nay, not send to me; 'tis false, he is not come; I wish he were not, I know not which I shou'd take more unkindly from him, exposing his life to his revengeful Enemies;
or being almost four and twenty hours so near me, and not let me know't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A Lovers dangers, are the only secrets kept from his Mistress; he came not to you, because he wou'd not purchase his happiness with your fear and apprehensions.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Nay, he is come, I see, since you are come about again of his side.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Will you go in, Madam, and disprove me if you can; 'tis better then standing in the street.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
We'le go a little farther first, and return.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I told you I had sent my man, to Christina's, this morning, to enquire of her Maid, (who seldom denies him a secret) if her Lady had been at the Park last night; which she peremptorily answered to the contrary, and assur'd him, she had not stirr'd out since your departure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will not Chamber-maids lye, Vincent?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Will not Ranger lie, Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The circumstances of his story prov'd it true.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Do you think so old a Master in the faculty, as he, will want the varnish of probability for his lies?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do you think a Woman, having the advantage of her Sex, and Education, under such a Mistress, will want impudence to dis-avow a truth, that might be prejudicial to that Mistress?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But if both testimonies are fallible; why will you needs believe his? we are apter to believe the things we wou'd have, then those we wou'd not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My ill luck has taught me to credit my mis-fortunes, and doubt my happiness.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But Fortune we know inconstant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And all of her Sex.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Will you judge of Fortune by your experience, and not do your Mistress the same justice? go see her, and satisfie your self and her; for if she be innocent, consider how culpable you
are, not only in your censures of her, but in not seeing her since your coming.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If she be innocent, I shou'd be afraid to surprize her, for her sake; if false, I shou'd be afraid to surprize her, for my own.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: To be jealous, and not inquisitive, is as hard as to love extreamly, and not be something jealous.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Inquisitiveness as seldom cures jealousie, as drinking in a Fever quenches the thirst.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: If she were at the Park last night, 'tis probable she'l not miss this; go watch her house, see who goes out, who in; while I in the mean time search out Ranger; who, I'le pawn my life, upon more discourse, shall avow his mistake; here he is, go in, how luckily is he come?

div.stage:
Valentine
retires to the dore behind, over hearing them.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ranger, you have prevented me; I was going to look you out, between the Scenes at the Play-houses, the Coffee-house, Tennis-Court, or Giffords.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Do you want a pretence to go to a Bawdy-house? but I have other visits to make.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I forget, I shou'd rather have sought you in Christina's lodgings, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Well, well, I am just come to tell you that Christina—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Proves not by day-light, the kind Lady you follow'd last night out of the Park.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I have better news for you, to my thinking.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Not that I have been in Christina's lodging this morning; but that she'l be presently here in your lodging with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How!
behind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
You see now, his report was a jest, a meer jest:
Drawing back to the dore, where
Valentine
stood, and speaking softly to him.
well, must my lodging be your Vaulting School still; thou hast appointed a Wench to come hither, I find.
To Ran.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: A Wench; you seem'd to have more reverence for Christina last night.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Now you talk of Christina, prethee tell me what was the meaning of thy last nights Romance of Christina.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You shall know the meaning of all, when Christina comes; she'l be here presently.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Who will, Christina?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Yes, Christina.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Incredulous envy; thou art as envious, as an impotent Letcher at a Wedding.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Thou art either mad, or as vain as a French-man, newly return'd home from a Campagn, or obliging England.

sp.speaker: Ran.
Vin.
sp.p: Do you think I take your secret as an obligation? don't, I know, Lovers, Travellers, and Poets, will give money to be heard; but what's the Paper? a Lampoon upon Christina, hatch'd last night betwixt Squire Dapperwit and you, because her maid us'd you scurvily.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: No, 'tis only a Letter from her, to shew, my company was not so disgustful to her last night, but that she desires it again to day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
A Letter from her.
Behind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l:
A Letter from Christina;
Reads.
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis pleasant.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You mistake, I laugh at you not the Letter.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I am like the winning Gamester, so pleas'd with my luck, I will not quarrel with any, who calls me a Fool for't.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Is this the stile of a woman of honour?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: It may be, for ought you know; I'm sure, 'tis well if your female correspondents can read.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I must confess, I have none of the little Letters, half name, or title, like your Spanish Epistles Dedicatory; but that a man so frequent in honourable Intrigues, as you are, should not know the summons of an impudent common woman, from that of a person of honour.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Christina is so much a Person of Honour, she'l own what she has writ, when she comes.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But will she come hither indeed?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Immediately, you'l excuse my liberty with you; I cou'd not conceal such a happiness, from such a friend as you, lest you shou'd have taken it unkindly.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Faith, you have oblig'd me indeed; for you, and others wou'd often have made me believe your honourable Intrigues, but never did me the honour to convince me of 'em before.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You are merry, I find, yet.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: When you are happy, I cannot be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
But I lose time, I shou'd lay a little Person in
Aside.
ambush, that lives hard by, in case Christina shou'd be impatient to be reveng'd of her Friends, as it often happens with a discontented Heiress; Women like old Souldiers, more nimbly execute, then they resolve.
Going out.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What now, you will not dis-appoint a woman of Christina's quality?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I'le be here before she comes, I warrant you.
Ex. Ran.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I do believe you truly: what think you Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I think, since she has the courage to challenge him; she'l have the honour of being first in the Field.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Fye, your opinion of her must be as bad, as Rangers of himself is good, to think she wou'd write to him; I long till his bona-roba comes, that you may be both dis-abus'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I have not patience to stay her coming, lest you shou'd be dis-abus'd.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Here she is i'faith; I'm glad she's come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I'm sorry; but I will to my post again, lest she shou'd say she came to me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
By heavens, Christina her self, 'tis she!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
'Tis she; curs'd be these eyes, more curs'd, then when they first betray'd me, to that false bewitching face.
Behind.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: You may wonder, Sir, to see me here—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I must confess I do.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: But the confidence your Friend has in you, is the cause of mine; and yet some blushes it do's cost me, to come to seek a man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Modest creature.
Behind.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
How am I deceiv'd!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Where is he, Sir, why does he not appear to keep me in countenance? pray call him, Sir, 'tis something hard if he shou'd know I'm here.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I hardly can, my self, believe you are here, Madam.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: If my visit be troublesome, or unseasonable, 'tis your Friends fault, I design'd it not to you, Sir; pray call him out, that he may excuse it, and take it on himself, together with my shame.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
How impatient she is!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Or do you delay the happiness I ask, to make it more welcom? I have stay'd too long for it already, and cannot more desire it; dear Sir, call him out, where is he? above, or here within? I'le snatch the favour which you will not give:
Goes to the dore, and discovers
Valentine.
What do you hide your self for shame?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I must confess I do.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: To see me come hither—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I acknowledge it.
Val.
offers to go out
.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Before you came to me; but whither do you go? come I can forgive you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But I cannot forgive you.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Whither do you go? you need not forge a quarrel, to prevent mine to you; nor need you try if I wou'd follow you; you know I will, I have you see.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
That impudence should look so like innocence.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Whither wou'd you go? why wou'd you go?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To call your servant to you.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: She is here, what wou'd you with her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I mean your Lover, the man you came to meet.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Oh heavens! what Lover? what Man? I came to seek no man but you, whom I had too long lost.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You cou'd not know that I was here.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Ask her, 'twas she that told me.
Points to
Isabel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How cou'd she know?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: That you shall know hereafter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, you thought me too far out of the way, to disturb your assignation; and I assure you, Madam, 'twas my ill fortune, not my design; and that it may appear so, I do withdraw, (as in all good breeding, and civility, I am oblig'd) for sure your wish'd for Lover's coming.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What do you mean? are you a weary of that title?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I am asham'd of it, since it grows common.
Going out.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Nay, you will not, shall not go.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My stay might give him jealousie, and so do you injury, and him the greatest in the world; Heavens forbid! I wou'd not make a man jealous; for though you call a thousand vows, and oaths, and tears, to witness, (as you safely may) that you have not the least of love for me; yet if he ever knew, how I have lov'd you, sure he wou'd not, cou'd not believe you.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I do confess, your Riddle is too hard for me to solve; therefore you are oblig'd to do't your self.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wish it were capable of any other interpretation, than what you know already.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Is this that generous good Valentine, who has disguis'd him so.
She weeps.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Nay, I must with-hold you then:
Stops Val.
going out
.
methinks she shou'd be innocent; her tongue, and eyes, together, with that floud that swells 'em, do vindicate her heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: They shew but their long practice of desimulation.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Come back; I hear Ranger coming up; stay but till he comes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do you think I have the patience of an Alderman?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You may go out this way, when you will, by the back-stairs; but stay a little, till— Oh, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
My revenge will now detain me.
Valen.
retires again
.

div.stage:
Vpon Rangers entrance, Christina
puts on her Mask
.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
What, come already? where is Dapperwit?
Aside.

The blessing's double that comes quickly; I did not yet expect
you here, otherwise I had not done my self the injury to be absent; but I hope, Madam, I have not made you stay long for me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I have not staid at all for you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I am glad of it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Is not this that troublesome stranger, who
To Isabel.
last night follow'd the Lady into my lodgings? 'tis he.
Aside.

div.stage: Removing from him to t'other side.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l:
Why do's she remove so disdainfully from me?
Aside.
I find you take it ill, I was not at your coming here, Madam.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Indeed I do not, you are mistaken, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Confirm me by a smile then, Madam; remove that Cloud, which makes me apprehend
Goes to take off her Mask.
foul weather: Mr. Vincent, pray retire; 'tis you keep on the Ladies Mask, and no displeasure, which she has for me; yet, Madam, you need not distrust his honour, or his faith; but do not keep the Lady under constraint; pray leave us a little Master Vincent.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: You must not leave us, Sir; wou'd you leave me with a stranger?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How's that!
Behind.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I've done amiss, I find, to bring her hither,
Aside.
Madam, I understand you—
Apart to
Christina.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Sir, I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You wou'd not be known to Mr. Vincent.

sp.speaker: Chris
sp.p: 'Tis your acquaintance I wou'd avoid.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Dull Brute, that I was, to bring her hither:
Aside.
I have found my error, Madam; give me but a new appointment, where I may meet you by and by, and straight I will withdraw, as if I knew you not.
Softly to her.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l:
I must not own it.
Aside.

No Madam, but—
Offers to whisper.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Whispering, Sir, argues an old acquaintance; but I have not the vanity to be thought of yours, and resolve you shall never have the disparagement of mine: Mr. Vincent, pray let us go in here.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
How's this! I am undone I see; but if I let her go
thus, I shall be an eternal laughing stock to Vincent.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Do you not know him, Madam? I thought you had come hither on purpose to meet him.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: To meet him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: By your own appointment.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What strange infatuation do's delude you all? you know, he said, he did not know me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You writ to him, he has your Letter.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Then you know my name sure? yet you confess'd but now, you knew me not.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I must confess, your anger has disguis'd you, more then your Mask; for I thought to have met a kinder Christina here.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Heavens! how cou'd he know me in this place? he watch'd me hither sure; or is there any other of my name, that you may no longer mistake me, for your Christina? I'le pull of that which sooths your error.
Pulls off her Mask.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Take but t'other vizard off too; I mean your anger, and i'le swear you are the same, and only Christina, which I wish'd, and thought to meet here.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: How cou'd you think to meet me here?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
By virtue of this your Commission,
Gives her the Letter.
which now, I see, was meant a real challenge; for you look, as if you wou'd fight with me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: The Paper is a stranger to me, I never writ it; you are abus'd.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Christina is a Person of Honour, and will own what she has written, Ranger.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
So, the Comedy begins; I shall be laugh'd at sufficiently, if I do not justifie my self; I must set my impudence to hers, she is resolv'd to deny all I see, and I have lost all hope of
Aside.
her.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Come, faith Ranger—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You will deny too, Madam, that I follow'd you last night from the Park, to your lodging, where I stay'd with you till morning; you never saw me before I warrant?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
That you rudely intruded, last night, into my lodging, I cannot deny; but I wonder you have the confidence to brag
of it; sure you will not of your reception?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I never was so ill-bred, as to brag of my reception in a Ladies Chamber; not a word of that, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How! if he lies, I revenge her; if it be true, I revenge my self.

div.stage:
Valentine
draws his Sword, which
Vincent
seeing, thrusts him back, and shuts the dore upon him before he was discover'd by
Ranger.

Enter Lydia
and her Woman, stopping at the dore.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
What do I see! Christina with him! a Counter-plot to mine, to make me, and it, ridiculous; 'tis true, I find they have been long acquainted, and I long abus'd; but since she intends a triumph, in spight, as well as shame (not emulation) I retire; she deserves no envy, who will be shortly in my condition; his natural inconstancy, will prove my best revenge on her— on both.
Exeunt Lydia
with her Woman
.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Christina's going away again; what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I scarce had paid the Chair-men, and was coming up after her, but I met her on the stairs, in as much haste, as if she had been frightn'd.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Who do you talk of?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Christina, whom I took up in a Chair, just now at Saint Jamses's Gate.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Thou art mad, here she is, this is Christina.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I must confess, I did not see her face; but I am sure the Lady is gone, that I brought just now.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: I tell you, again, this is she; did you bring two?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I came in no Chair, had no guide, but my woman there.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: When did you bring your Lady, Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Ev'n now, just now.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: This Lady has been here half an hour.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: He knows not what he says, he is mad, you are all so, I am so too.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
'Tis the best excuse you can make for your self, and by owning your mistake, you'l shew you are come to your self; I
my self saw your woman at the dore, who but look'd in, and then immediately went down again, as your friend Dapperwit too affirms.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: You had best follow her, that look'd for you; and i'le go seek out him, I came to see; Mr. Vincent, pray let me in here.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: 'Tis very fine, wondrous fine!

div.stage:
Christina
goes out a little, and returns.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Oh he is gone! Mr. Vincent, follow him; he were yet more severe to me, in indangering his life, then in his censures of me; you know the power of his Enemies is great, as their malice; just Heaven preserve him from them, and me from this ill, or unlucky man.
Ex. Christina,
her Woman, and
Vincent.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: 'Tis well— nay, certainly, I shall never be master of my Senses more; but why do'st thou help to distract me too?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: My astonishment was as great as yours, to see her go away again; I wou'd have stay'd her if I cou'd.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Yet, again, talking of a woman you met going out, when I talk of Christina.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I talk of Christina too.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: She went out just now; the woman you found me with, was she.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
That was not the
Christina I
brought just now.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You brought her, almost, half an hour ago; s'death, will you give me the lye?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
A Lady disappointed by her Gallant, the night before her journey, cou'd not be more touchy with her Maid, or Husband, then you are with me now, after your dis-appointment; but if you thank me so, i'le go serve my self hereafter; for ought I know, I have dis-appointed Mrs. Martha for you, and may lose thirty thousand pound by the bargain: farewel, a raving Lover is fit for solitude.
Ex. Dap.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Lydia, triumph, I now am thine again; of Intrigues, honourable or dishonourable, and all sorts of rambling, I take my leave; when we are giddy, 'tis time to stand still: why shou'd we be so fond of the by-paths of Love? where we are still way-lay'd, with Surprizes, Trapans, Dangers, and Murdering dis-appointments:
sp.l: Just as at Blind-mans Buff, we run at all,
Whilst those that lead us, laugh to see us fall;
And when we think, we hold the Lady fast,

We find it but her Scarf, or Veil, at last.
Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE. I. St. James's Park.
div.stage:
Enter Sir
Simon Addleplot,
leading Mrs.
Martha, Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: AT length, you see, I have freed the Captive Lady, for her longing Knight. Mr. Dapperwit, who brings off a Plot cleverly now.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I wish our Poets were half so good at it; Mrs. Martha, a thousand welcoms—

div.stage:
Dapperwit
Kisses and Embraces Mrs.
Martha.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; your joy is a little too familiar, (faith and troth.)

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Will you not let me salute Mrs. Martha?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: What Jonas, do you think I do not know good breeding? must I be taught by you?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I wou'd have kept the Maiden-head of your lips, for your sweet Knight, Mrs. Martha, that's all; I dare swear, you never kiss'd any man before, but your Father.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: My sweet Knight, if he will be a Knight of mine, must be contented with what he finds, as well as other Knights.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim,
sp.p: So smart already, faith and troth!

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Dear, Mr. Dapperwit, I am over-joy'd to see you; but I thank honest Jonas for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
How she hugs him!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Poor, Mr. Dapperwit, I thought I shou'd never have seen you again; but I thank honest Jonas there—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do not thank me, Mrs. Martha, any more then I thank you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I wou'd not be ungrateful, Jonas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Then reserve your kindness, only, for your Worthy Noble, Brave, Heroick Knight; who loves you only, and only deserves your kindness.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p:
I will shew my kindness to my Worthy, Brave, Heroick Knight, in being kind to his Friend, his dear Friend, who help'd him to me.
Hugs Dap. again.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
