sp.p: But, Mistress Martha, he is not to help him always; though he helps him to be married, he is not to help him when he is married.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: What, Mr. Dapperwit, will you love my worthy Knight, less after marriage, then before? that were against the custom; for marriage gets a man friends, instead of losing those he has.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I will ever be his Servant, and yours; Dear, Madam, do not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p:
I do not, sweet, dear, Mr. Dapperwit; but I shou'd not have seen you these two days, if it had not been for honest Jonas, there—
She Kisses
Dap.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
For shame, though she be young and foolish, do not you wrong me to my face.
Apart to
Dap.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Wou'd you have me so ill bred, as to repulse her innocent kindness; what a thing it is to want Wit!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
A Pox, I must make haste to discover my self, or I shall discover, what I wou'd not discover; but if I shou'd discover my self in this habit, 'twou'd not be to my advantage; but i'le go, put on my own cloaths, and look like a Knight:
Aside.
Well, Mrs. Martha, i'le go seek out your Knight; are you not impatient to see him?
To her.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Wives must be obedient, let him take his own time.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Can you trust your self, a turn or two, with Master Dapperwit?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Jonas, as long as you will.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
But I wou'd not trust you with him, if I could help it;
Aside.
sp.l: So marry'd Wight, sees what he dares not blame;

And cannot budge for fear, nor stay for shame.
Ex. S. Sim.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
I am glad he is gone, that I may laugh; 'tis such a miracle of Fops, that his conversation shou'd be pleasant to me,
even when it hindred me of yours.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Indeed, i'm glad he is gone too, as pleasant as he is.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I know why, I know why, sweet Mrs. Martha; I warrant you, you had rather have the Parsons company, then his? now you are out of your Fathers house, 'tis time to leave being a Hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Well, for the jests sake, to dis-appoint my Knight, I wou'd not care if I dis-appointed my self of a Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Come, I will not keep you on the Tenters, I know you have a mind to make sure of me; I have a little Chaplain, I wish he were a Bishop, or one of the Fryars, to perfect our revenge upon that Zealous Jew, your Father.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Do not speak ill of my Father, he has been your friend, i'm sure.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: My Friend—

sp.speaker: Mar·
sp.p: His hard usage of me, conspir'd with your good Meen, and Wit, and to avoid slavery under him, I stoop to your yoke.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I will be obliged to your Father, for nothing but a portion, nor to you for your love; 'twas due to my merit.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You shew your self Sir Simons original, if 'twere not for that vanity—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I shou'd be no wit, 'tis the badge of my calling; for you can no more find a man of wit without vanity, then a fine woman without affectation: But let us go, before the Knight comes again.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Let us go before my Father comes, he soon will have the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Stay, let me think a little.
Pauses.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: What are you thinking of? you shou'd have thought before this time, or, I shou'd have thought rather.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: What are you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I am thinking, what a Wit without vanity is like; he is like—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You do not think we are in a publick place, and may be surpriz'd, and prevented by my Fathers Scouts.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, wou'd you have me lose my thought?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You wou'd rather lose your Mistress, it seems.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: He is like— I think i'm a Sot to night, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Nay, if you are so in love with your thought.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Are you so impatient to be my Wife? he is like— he is like— a Picture without shadows, or, or— a Face without Patches— or a Diamond without a Foyl; these are new thoughts now, these are new.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You are wedded already to your thoughts, I see, good night.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Madam, do not take it ill;
For loss of happy thought, there's no amends.
For his new jest, true Wit will lose old Friends.

That's new again, the thought's new.
Exeunt.

div.stage:
Enter Gripe,
leading Mrs.
Lucy, Joyner, Crossbite following.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Mrs. Joyner, I can conform to this mode of publick walking by Moon-light, because one is not known.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why, are you asham'd of your company?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, Pretty one; because in the dark, or as it were the dark, there is no envy, nor scandal; I wou'd neither lose you, nor my reputation.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Your reputation; indeed, your Worship, 'tis well known, there are as grave men, as your Worship; nay, men in office too, that adjourn their cares, and businesses, to come and unbend themselves at night here, with a little vizard mask.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I do believe it, I do believe it, Mrs. Joyner.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I God-mother, and carries, and treats her at Mulberry Garden.

sp.speaker: Cros,
sp.p: Nay, do's not only treat her, but gives her his whole gleanings of that day.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: They may, they may Mrs. Crossbite, they take above six in the hundred.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Nay, there are those of so much worth, and honour, and love, that they'l take it from their Wives and Children, to give it to their Misses; now your Worship has no Wife, and but one Child.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Still for my Edification.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: That's true indeed, for I know a great Lady, that cannot follow her Husband abroad to his Haunts, because her Farrendine is so ragged and greasie; whilst his Mistress is as fine as sippence, in her embroidered Satens.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Politickly done of him indeed; if the truth were known, he is a States-man by that, umph—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Truly, your women of quality, are very troublesom to their Husbands; I have heard 'em complain, they will allow them no separate maintainance, though the honourable Jilts, themselves, will not marry without it.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Come, come, Mistress, sometimes 'tis the craft of those Gentlemen, to complain of their Wives expences, to excuse their own narrowness to their Misses; but your Daughter has a Gallant can make no excuse.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: So Mrs. Joyner— my friend Mrs. Joyner—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I hope, indeed, he'l give my Daughter no cause to dun him; for, poor wretch, she is as modest as her Mother.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I profess, I believe it.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But, I have the boldness to ask him for a Treat; come Gallant, we must walk towards the Mulberry Gard'n.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: So— I am afraid, little Mistress, the rooms are all taken up by this time.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Will you shame your self again?
Aside to
Gripe.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If the rooms be full, we'l have an arbor.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: At this time of night; besides, the Waiters will ne'r come near you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: They will be observant of good Customers, as we shall be; come along.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Indeed, and verily, little Mistress, I wou'd go, but that I shou'd be forsworn, if I did.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: That's so pitiful an excuse—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: In truth, I have forsworn the place, ever since I was pawn'd there for a reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You have broken many an Oath for the good old cause, and will you boggle at one for your poor, little Miss? come along.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Unfortunate Lady, that I am! I have left the Herd on purpose to be chas'd, and have wandred this hour here; but the Park affords not so much as a Satyr for me, (and that's strange) no Burgundy man, or drunken Scourer will reel my way; the Rag-women, and Synder-women, have better luck then I— but who are these? if this mungril light do's not deceive me, 'tis my brother, 'tis he, there's Joyner too, and two other women; I'le follow 'em; it must be he, for this world hath nothing like him; I know not what the Devil may be in the other.
Ex. Omnes.

div.stage:
Enter Sir
Simon Addleplot
in fine cloaths
, Dapperwit,
and Mrs.
Martha,
unseen by him at the dore.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Well, after all my seeking, I can find those I wou'd not find; i'm sure 'twas old Gripe, and Joyner with him, and the Widow follow'd; he wou'd not have been here, but to have sought his Daughter, sure; but vigilant Dapperwit has spy'd him too, and has, no doubt, secur'd her from him.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
And you.
Behind.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: The Rogue is as good at hiding, as I am at stealing a Mistress; 'tis a vain conceited fellow, yet I think, 'tis an honest fellow: but again, he is a damnable Whoring fellow; and what opportunity this air, and darkness may encline 'em to, Heaven knows; for I have heard the Rogue say himself, a Lady will no more shew her modesty in the dark, then a Spaniard his courage.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, if you are there my true Friend, i'le forgive your harkning, if you'l forgive my censures? I speak to you, dear, Madam Martha; dear, dear— Behold your worthy Knight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's far from neighbours.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I's come to reap the fruit of all his labours.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I cannot see the Knight; well, but i'm sure I hear Jonas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I am no Jonas, Mrs. Martha.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: The night is not so dark, nor the Perruque so big, but I can discern Jonas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Faith and troth, I am the very Sir
Simon Addleplot
, that is to marry you; the same, Dapperwit solicited you for; ask him else, my name is not Jonas.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You think my youth, and simplicity, capable of this cheat; but let me tell you, Jonas, 'tis not your borrow'd cloaths, and title, shall make me marry my Fathers man.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Borrow'd title; i'le be sworn I bought it of my Landress, who was a Court Landress; but, indeed, my cloaths I have not pay'd for, therefore in that sense they are borrow'd.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Prethee, Jonas, let the jest end, or I shall be presently in earnest.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Pray be in earnest, and let us go; the Parson, and Supper, stay for us, and I am a Knight in earnest.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You a Knight, insolent, sawcy Fool?

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: The Devil take me, Mrs. Martha, if I am not a Knight now; a Knight Baronet too: a man ought, I see, to carry his Patent in his Pocket, when he goes to be marry'd, 'tis more necessary then a License; I am a Knight indeed, and, indeed now, Mrs. Martha.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Indeed, and indeed, the trick will not pass, Jonas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Poor wretch, she's afraid, she shall not be a Lady: come, come, discover the Intrigue, Dapperwit—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: You need not discover the Intrigue, 'tis apparent already; unworthy Mr. Dapperwit, after my confidence repos'd in you; cou'd you be so little generous, as to betray me to my Fathers man? but i'le be even with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Do not accuse him, poor man, before you hear him; tell her the intrique man.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: A Pox, she will not believe us.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Will you not excuse your self? but I must not let it rest so; know then Mrs. Martha—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Come, I forgive thee before thy confession, Jonas; you never had had the confidence to have design'd this cheat upon me, but from Mr. Dapperwits encouragement, 'twas his Plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Nay, do not do me that wrong, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: But since he has trapan'd me out of my Fathers house, he is like to keep me as long as I live; and so good night, Jonas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what d'y ' mean both? prethee tell her I am Sir Simon, and no Jonas.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: A Pox, she will not believe us, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I have provided a Parson, and Supper, at Mulberry Gard'n, and invited all my Friends I cou'd meet in the Park.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Nay, rather then they shall be dis-appointed, there shall be a Bride and Bridegroom, to entertain 'em; Mrs. Martha, and i'le go thither presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Why, shall she be your Bride?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: You see she will have it so.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Will you make Dapperwit your Husband?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Rather then my Fathers man.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Oh the Devil—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Nay, come along Jonas, you shall make one at the Wedding, since you help'd contrive it.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Will you cheat your self, for fear of being cheared?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I am desperate now.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: Wilt thou let her do so ill a thing, Dapperwit, as to marry thee? open her eyes, prethee, and tell her I am a true Knight.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be in vain, by my life, you have carry'd your self so like a natural Clerk— and so adieu good Jonas.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: What, ruin'd by my own Plot, like an old Cavalier: yet like him too, I will plot on still, a plot of prevention, so I have it— her Father was here ev'n now, i'm sure; well— I'le go tell her Father of her, that I will;
sp.l: And punish so her folly, and his treachery,

Revenge is sweet, and makes amends for leachery.
Ex.

div.stage:
Enter Lydia,
and her Woman
Leonore.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I wish, I had not come hither to night, Leonore.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Why did you, Madam? if the place be so dis-agreeable to you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: We cannot help visiting the place often, where we have lost any thing we value; I lost Ranger here last night.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You thought you had lost him before, a great while ago; and therefore you ought to be the less troubled.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But 'twas here, I miss'd him first, i'm sure.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let not the loss vex you, he is not worth the looking after.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: It cannot but vex me yet, if I lost him by my own fault.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: You had but too much care to keep him.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: It often happens, indeed, that too much care, is as bad as negligence; but I had rather be rob'd, then lose what I have carelesly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But, I believe, you wou'd hang the Thief, if you cou'd.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Not if I cou'd have my own again.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I see, you wou'd be too merciful.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: I wish I were try'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But, Madam, if you please, we will wave the discourse; for people seldom (I suppose) talk with pleasure, of their real losses.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: 'Tis better then to ruminate in them; mine, i'm sure, will not out of my head, nor heart.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Grief is so far from retrieving a loss, that it makes it greater; but the way to lesson it, is, by a comparison with others losses; here are Ladies, in the Park, of your acquaintance, I doubt not, can compare with you; pray, Madam, let us walk and find 'em out.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
'Tis the resentment, you say, makes the loss great, or little; and then i'm sure, there is none like mine; however go on.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I am glad I have found you, for now I am prepar'd to lead you out of the dark, and all your trouble; I have good news.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are as unmerciful, as the Physician, who with new Arts, keeps his miserable Patient alive, and in hopes, when he knows the disease is incurable.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And you, like the melancholy Patient, mistrust, and hate your Physician, because he will not comply with your despair: but i'le cure your jealousie now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You know, all Diseases grow worse by relapses.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Trust me once more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, you may try your experiments upon me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Just as I shut the dore upon you, the woman, Ranger, expected, came up stairs; but finding another woman in discourse with him, went down again, I suppose, as jealous of him, as you of Christina.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How do's it appear she came to Ranger?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Thus, Dapperwit came up after, who had brought her, just then, in a Chair from St. Jamses's, by Rangers appointment; and it is certain your Christina came to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How can that be? for she knew not I was in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: My man confesses, when I sent him to enquire of her woman, about her Lady's being here in the Park last night; he told her you were come, and she, it seems, told her Mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
That might be—
Aside.
But did not Christina confess, Ranger was in her lodging last night?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: By intrusion, which she had more particularly inform'd me of, if her apprehensions of your danger had not posted me after you; she not having yet (as I suppose) heard of Clerimonts recovery: I left her, poor creature, at home, distracted with a thousand fears for your life and love.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Her love, i'm sure, has cost me more fears, then my life; yet that little danger is not past, (as you think) till the great one be over.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Open but your eyes, and the Fantastick Goblin's vanish'd, and all your idle fears, will turn to shame; for Jealousie, is the basest cowardize.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I had rather, indeed, blush for my self, then her.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I'm sure you will have more reason—
But is not that Ranger there?

div.stage:
Ranger
enters, follow'd by
Christina
and her Woman, after them,
Lydia
and her Woman
.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I think it is.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I suppose, his friend Dapperwit is not far off; I will examine them both before you, and not leave you so much, as the shadow of a doubt; Rangers astonishment at my lodging, confess'd his mistake.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: His astonishment might proceed from Christina's unexpected strangeness to him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: He shall satisfie you now himself to the contrary, I warrant you, have but patience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I had rather, indeed, he shou'd satisfie my doubts, then my revenge; therefore I can have patience.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But what women are those that follow him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Stay a little—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Lydia, Lydia
— poor Lydia.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
If she be my Rival, 'tis some comfort yet,
To her Maid.
to see her follow him, rather then he her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: But if you follow them a little longer, for your comfort, you shall see them go hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Sir, Sir—
To Ranger.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: She calls to him already.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But he do's not hear, you see; let us go a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Sure it is Ranger?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As sure as the woman that follows him closest, is Christina.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: For shame, talk not of Christina; I left her just now at home, surrounded with so many fears and griefs, she cou'd not stir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She is come, it may be, to divert them here in the Park; I'm sure 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: When the Moon, at this instant, scarce affords light enough to distinguish a man from a tree, how can you know her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How can you know Ranger, then?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I heard him speak.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So you may her too; i'le secure you, if you will draw but a little nearer: she came, doubtless, to no other end but to speak with him; observe—

sp.speaker: Chris.
Ran.
sp.p: Ha! is not this Christina's voice? it is I am sure, I cannot be deceiv'd now— dear Madam—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
It is she indeed.
Apart to
Val.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is it so?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
Come, Sir—
To Ranger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Nay, I'le follow you too, though not invited,
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
I must not, cannot stay behind.
Aside.
Exeunt.

div.stage:
They all go off together in a huddle, hastily
; Christina,
her Woman, and
Valentine,
return on the other side
.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Come along, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
So I must stick to her when all is done; her new servant has lost her in the crowd, she has gone too fast for him; so much my revenge is swifter then his love: now shall I not only have the deserted Lovers revenge, of dis-appointing her of her new man; but an opportunity infallibly at once, to discover her falseness, and confront her impudence.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Pray come along, Sir, I am in haste.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
So eager, indeed— I wish that Cloud may yet with-hold the Moon, that this false Woman, may not discover me, before I do her.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Here no one can hear us, and i'm sure we cannot see one another.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: S'death, what have I giddily run my self upon?
'Tis rather a tryal of my self then her;

I cannot undergo it.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Come nearer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Hell and vengeance, I cannot suffer it, I cannot.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Come, come; yet nearer, pray come nearer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is impossible, I cannot hold; I must discover my self, rather then her infamy.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: You are conscious, it seems, of the wrong you have done me, and are asham'd, though in the dark.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How's this!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I'm glad to find it so; for all my business with you, is to show you your late mistakes, and force a confession from you, of those unmannerly injuries you have done me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
What! I think she's honest; or do's she know me? sure she cannot.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: First, your intrusion, last night, into my lodging, which I suppose, has begot your other gross mistakes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
No, she takes me for Ranger, I see again.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: You are to know then, (since needs you must) it was not me you follow'd last night to my lodging, from the Park, but some Kinswoman of yours, it seems; whose fear of being discover'd by you, prevail'd with me to personate her, while she withdrew, our Habits and our Statures being much alike; which I did with as much difficulty, as she us'd importunity to make me; and all this, my Lady Flippant can witness, who was then with your Cousin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I am glad to hear this—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Now, what your claim to me, at Mr. Vincent's lodging meant; the letter, and promises, you unworthily, or erroneously lay'd to my charge, you must explain to me and others, or—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How's this! I hope I shall discover no guilt but my own; she wou'd not speak in threats to a Lover—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Was it because you found me in Mr. Vincent's lodgings, you took a liberty to use me, like one of your common Visitants? But know, I came no more to Mr. Vincent, then to to you; yet, I confess, my visit was intended to a man— A brave man, till you made him use a woman ill, worthy the love of a Princess; till you made him censure mine; good as Angels, till you made him unjust; why— in the name of honour, wou'd you do't?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
How happily, am I dis-appointed! poor injur'd Christina.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
He wou'd have sought me out first, if you had not made him flye from me; our mutual love, confirm'd by a contract, made our hearts inseparable; till you rudely, if not maliciously, thrust in upon us, and broke the close, and happy knot: I had lost him before for a month, now for ever.
She weeps.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
My joy, and pity, makes me as mute, as my shame; yet I must discover my self.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Your silence, is a confession of your guilt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I own it.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p:
But that will not serve my turn; for strait you must go clear your self, and me, to him you have injur'd in me; if he has not made too much haste from me, to be found again;
you must, I say, for he is a man that will have satisfaction; and in satisfying him, you do me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then he is satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: How! is it you? then I am not satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you be worse then your word?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I gave it not to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, dear Christina, the Jealous, like the Drunkard, has his punishment, with his offence.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Valentine, Mr. Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Vincent—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Where have you been all this while?

div.stage:
Valentine holds Christina
by the hand, who seems to struggle to get from him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Here, with my injur'd Christina.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: She's behind with Ranger, who is forc'd to speak all the tender things himself; for she affords him not a word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pish, pish, Vincent, who is blind now? who deceiv'd now?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You are, for I'm sure Christina is with him; come back and see.

div.stage: They go out at one dore, and return at the other.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Still mock'd, still abus'd! did you not bid me follow you, where we might not be disturb'd, nor over-heard? and now not allow me a word?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Did you hear him?
Apart to
Val.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, peace—
Apart to
Vin.

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p: Disowning your Letter, and me, at Vincent's lodging, declaring you came to meet another there, and not me; with a great deal of such affronting unkindness, might be reasonable enough, because you wou'd not intrust Vincent with our love; but now, when no body sees us, nor hears us, why this unseasonable shyness?—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
It seems, she did not expect him there, but had appointed to meet another; I wish it were so.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I have not Patience; do you design thus to revenge my
intrusion into your lodging last night? sure if you had then been displeas'd with my company, you wou'd not have invited your self to't again by a Letter? or is this a punishment for bringing you to a house, so near your own, where, it seems, you were known too? I do confess, it was a fault; but make me suffer any Penance, but your Silence, because it is the certain mark of a Mistress's lasting displeasure—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
My cue is not yet come.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Not yet a word? you did not use me so unkindly last night, when you chid me out of your house, and with indignation bid me be gone; now, you bid me follow you, and yet will have nothing to say to me; and I am more deceiv'd this day and night, then I was last night; when, I must confess, I follow'd you for another.—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
I'm glad to hear that.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: One that wou'd have us'd me better; whose love, I have ungratefully abus'd for yours; yet from no other reason, but my natural inconstancy—

Poor
Lydia, Lydia
—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
He mutter'd my name sure, and with a sigh.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But as last night, by following (as I thought) her, I found you: so this night, by following you in vain, I do resolve, if I can find her again, to keep her for ever.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
Now I am obliged, and brought in debt to his inconstancy; faith, now cannot I hold out any longer, I must discover my self.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: But, Madam, because I intend to see you no more, i'le take my leave of you for good and all; since you will not speak, i'le try if you will squeek—

div.stage: Goes to throw her down, she squeeks.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Mr. Ranger, Mr. Ranger—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Fye, fye, you need not ravish Christina sure, that loves you so.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Is it she! Lydia all this while? how am I gull'd, and. Vincent in the Plot too?

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Now false Ranger.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Now false Christina too; you thought I did not know you now, because I offer'd you such an unusual civility.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: You knew me, I warrant you knew too, that I was the Christina you follow'd out of the Park last night; that I was the Christina that writ the Letter too.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Certainly, therefore I wou'd have taken my revenge, you see, for your tricks.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Is not this the same woman that took refuge in your house last night, Madam?
To Christina.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, Mr. Ranger, we have chop'd, and chang'd, and hid our Christina's so long, and often, that at last, we have drawn each of us our own?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Mr. Valentine in England! the truth on't is, you have jugled together, and drawn without my knowledge; but since she will have it so, she shall wear me for good and all now.

div.stage: Goes to take her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Come not near me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Nay, you need not be afraid, I wou'd ravish you, now I know you.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p:
And yet, Leonore, I think 'tis but justice, to pardon the fault, I made him commit?
Apart to
Leonore, Ranger listens.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You consider it right, Cousin; for indeed, you are but merciful to your self in it.

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: Yet, if I wou'd be rigorous, though I made the blot, your over-sight has lost the game.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
But 'twas rash womans play, Cousin, and ought not to be play'd again, let me tell you.
Dap.
to them
.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Who's there? who's there?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Dapperwit.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Mr. Ranger, I am glad I have met with you; for I have left my Bride just now, in the house at Mulberry Garden, to come and pick up some of my Friends in the Park here, to sup with us.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Your Bride! are you marry'd then? where is your Bride?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Here at Mulberry Garden, I say, where you, these Ladies, and Gentlemen, shall all be welcome, if you will afford me the honour of your company.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: With all our hearts; but who have you marry'd, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, do you think I wou'd marry a Wench? I have marry'd an Heiress worth thirty thousand pound, let me perish.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: An Heiress worth thirty thousand pound!

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Mr. Vincent, your servant, you here too?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Nay, we are more of your acquaintance here (I think) go, we'le follow you, for if you have not dismiss'd your Parson, perhaps we may make him more work.
Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene changes to the Dining-room, in Mulberry-Garden-house.

Enter Sir
Simon Addleplot, Gripe, Mrs. Martha, Joyner, Crossbite, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis as I told you, Sir, you see.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Oh graceless Babe, marry'd to a Wit! an idle, loytering, slandering, foul-mouth'd, beggarly Wit; Oh that my child should ever live to marry a Wit!

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p: Indeed, your Worship had better seen her fairly buried, as they say.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: If my Daughter, there, shou'd have done so, I wou'd not have gi'n her a groat.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Marry a Wit!

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Mrs. Joyner, do not let me lose the
To Joyner.
Widow too; for if you do, (betwixt friends) I and my small annuity are both blown up; it will follow my estate.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
I warrant you.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p:
Let us make sure of Sir Simon to night,
To Joyner.
or—
Aside.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
You need not fear it, like the Lawyers, while my Clients endeavour to cheat one another; I in justice cheat' emboth.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Marry a Wit!

div.stage: Enter Dapperwit, Ranger, and Lydia, Valentine, Christina, and Vincent.

Dapperwit
stops 'em, and they stand all behind.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
What is he here, Lucy and her Mother?
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Tell me how thou cam'st to marry a Wit?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Pray be not angry, Sir, and i'le give you a good reason.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Reason for marrying a Wit!

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Indeed, I found my self six months gone with Child, and saw no hopes of your getting me a Husband, or else I had not marryed a Wit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Joyn.
sp.p:
Then you were the Wit..
Aside.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Had you that reason? nay, then—

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
How's that!
Aside.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Who wou'd have thought, Dapperwit, you wou'd have marryed a Wench?
Aside.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
Well, thirty thousand pound will make me amends; I have known my betters wink, and fall on for five or six.
To Ran.
What, you are come, Sir, to give me joy?
To Gripe
and the rest
.
you Mrs. Lucy, you, and you? well, unbid guests are doubly welcom—

Sir Simon, I made bold to invite these Ladies,
To Sir
Simon.
and Gentlemen, for you must know, Mr. Ranger, this worthy Sir Simon, do's not only give me my Wedding Supper, but my Mistress too; and is as it were my Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p:
Then I am as it were a Grand-father to your new Wives,
hans en kelder
; to which you are but as it were a Father; there's for you again, Sir— ha ha—

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha—
To Vincent.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Fools sometimes say unhappy things, if we wou'd mind 'em, but— what, Melancholy at your Daughters Wedding, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
How deplorable is my condition?
Aside.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Nay, if you will rob me of my Wench, Sir, can you blame me for robbing you of your Daughter? I cannot be without a Woman.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
My Daughter, my Reputation, and my Money gone— but the last is dearest to me; yet at once I may retrieve that, and be reveng'd for the loss of the other; and all this by marrying Lucy here: I shall get my five hundred pound again, and get Heirs to exclude my Daughter, and frustrate Dapperwit; besides, 'tis agreed on all hands, 'tis cheaper keeping a Wife then a Wench.
Aside.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: If you are so melancholy, Sir, we will have the Fiddles, and a Dance to divert you; come.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Indeed, you have put me so upon a merry pin, that I resolve to marry too.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Nay, if my Brother come to marrying once, I may too; I swore I wou'd, when he did, little thinking—

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: I take you at your word, Madam.

sp.speaker: Flip.
sp.p: Well, but if I had thought you wou'd have been so quick with me—

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Where is your Parson?

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: What, you wou'd not revenge your self upon the Parson?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No, I wou'd have the Parson revenge me upon you; he shou'd marry me.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I am glad you are so frolick, Sir; but who wou'd you marry?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
This innocent Lady.
Pointing to
Lucy.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: That innocent Lady?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Nay, I am impatient, Mrs. Joyner, pray fetch him up, if he be yet in the house.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: We were not marry'd here; but you cannot be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You'l find it so; since you have rob'd me of my House-keeper, I must get another.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: Why? she was my Wench.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I'le make her honest then.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Upon my repute he never saw her before: but will your Worship marry my Daughter then?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I promise her, and you, before all this good company, to morrow I will make her my Wife.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Rang.
sp.p:
Our Ladies, Sir, I suppose, expect the same
To Val.
promise from us.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: They may be sure of us without a promise; but let us (if we can) obtain theirs, to be sure of them.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p:
But will you marry her to morrow?—
To Gripe.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I will verily.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.p: I am undone then, ruin'd let me perish.

sp.speaker: Sir Sim.
sp.p: No, you may hire a little room in Covent-Garden, and set up a Coffee-house; you, and your Wife, will be sure of the Wits custom.

sp.speaker: Dap.
sp.l: Abus'd by him, I have abus'd!
Fortune our foe, we cannot over-wit,
By none but thee, our projects are Cross-bit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, dear Madam, what yet angry? jealousie sure is much more pardonable before marriage, then after it; but to morrow, by the help of the Parson, you will put me out of all my fears.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I am afraid then you wou'd give me my revenge, and make me jealous of you; and I had rather suspect your faith, then you shou'd mine.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Cousin Lydia, I had rather suspect your faith too, then you shou'd mine; therefore let us even marry to morrow, that I may have my turn of watching, doging, standing under the window at the dore, behind the hanging or—

sp.speaker: Lyd.
sp.p: But if I cou'd be desperate now, and give you up my liberty; cou'd you find in your heart to quit all other engagements, and voluntarily turn your self over to one woman, and she a Wife too? cou'd you away with the insupportable bondage of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: You talk of Matrimony as irreverently, as my Lady Flippant; the Bondage of Matrimony, no—
sp.l: The end of Marriage, now is liberty,
And two are bound— to set each other free.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p:
PAge 3. line 11. read of a Woman, p. 4. l. 3. r. Is he here? p. 14. l. 9. r. this Jilt. p. 23. l. 2. r. lead her, p. 25. l. 9. r. she, p. 36. l. 20.
r. Ran.
five doors off on the right hand, p. ●0. l. 23. r. into the Play-house, p. 40. l. 27. r. sick with envy, p. 52. l. 1. r. setting a Chair, p. 84. l. 1. r. ruminate on them.

div.head: Epilogue
div.l: NOW my Brisk Brothers of the Pit, you'l say,
I'm come to speak a good word for the Play;
But (Gallants) let me perish, if I do,
For I have Wit, and judgment, just like you;
Wit never partial, judgment free and bold,
For fear or friendship never bought or sold,
Nor by good Nature, e're to be Cajol'd.
Good Nature in a Critick were a crime,
Like mercy in a Judge, and renders him
Guilty of all those faults, he do's forgive:
Besides, if Thief from Gallows you reprieve,
He'll cut your Throat; so Poet sav'd from shame,
In damn'd Lampoon, will murder your good name.
Yet in true spight to him, and to his Play,
(Good faith) you shou'd not rayl at 'em to day;
But to be more his Foe, seem most his Friend,
And so maliciously, the Play commend,
That he may be betray'd to Writing on,
And Poet let him be, to be undone.
